These sites are very attractive to children: they comprise a myriad games, graphics, music, virtual casino walk-in sites, live streamed broadcasts—all sorts of wonderful, exciting interactive technology. I know that some sites ask for the identity and the age of the gambler, but I have only to look at my 12-year-old son using the computer and Internet technology to know that children can bypass such measures. They are very clever at avoiding screening, and I have seen them do it time and time again. There is no evidence to suggest that children will not adopt this gambling technology, and that is a concern—especially as some 39 per cent of couples with children have Internet access at home. We should look at that issue more closely and consider the impact that gambling will have on the home.

The member for Melbourne Ports spoke earlier about a number of measures, and I was interested in how he was able to bring the telecard affair into a debate about gambling. When the Commonwealth met the states and territories on 19 April 2000 to discuss halting the growth of interactive gambling and adopting some sort of integrated approach, New South Wales and Western Australia were the only states to indicate support for that initiative. I note that Queensland was not particularly interested in getting involved. I wonder whether that had anything to do with the granting of Internet licences to some members of the Beattie government—a revelation that caused quite a scandal. I thought that was rather extraordinary.

talk.start.para: —Didn't he get rid of them?

—Yes, following a public outcry and after the Treasurer was exposed. It is hypocritical for the honourable member to talk about gambling behaviour when Queensland government ministers had interests in Internet licences. One must ask whether Labor's approach to gambling is balanced and partisan when Queensland ministers were granted Internet licences. The Premier did something about it—thank goodness—but only following a public outcry.

speech.para: I support this important bill. The moratorium is a good thing and we must look to conducting some sort of study of the industry. We need to consider the feasibility and consequences of the interactive gambling industry—regardless of whether a short-term moratorium is in place—which will continue to establish itself in Australia.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure that it will come as no surprise to you—this is our second meeting this morning—to learn that I support strongly the position adopted by the Labor Party that was advocated by our shadow minister for communications, the honourable member for Perth, this morning. I particularly support the amendments that will be considered and voted on at the conclusion of this debate on the Interactive Gambling (Moratorium) Bill 2000. I think it is worth pointing out that I find the inherent hypocrisy of this legislation, the internal contradictions within it and its unworkability quite outstanding. I have some knowledge of this industry, and I believe this legislation will not stop Australians gambling on the Internet.
—They'll just go offshore and support foreign operators.

—Foreign shonky operators. Anyone with any understanding of how the Internet works will know that you cannot put a bridge in place to prevent Australians gambling on the Internet. Let me make it very clear: there are three licensed Internet gambling operations in the Northern Territory: two racing and gaming operations, sports betting operations; and Lasseters Casino. Lasseters Casino, just for information's sake, is turning over currently $210 million and has 85,000 players. The bulk of these players are from overseas. I have looked at the Centrebet operation in Alice Springs, its online gambling, its racing and waging, which is not covered by this legislation any more and—I think I am correct in saying this—about 85 per cent to 90 per cent of its custom is overseas. What gamblers are after when they log into these sites in Australia is an understanding that we have well-regulated sites and good governance overriding their operation. They know that it is a market attraction to be able to gamble off Australian sites. What we are seeing now is the potential to push this market into a position where they will be dealing with gambling operations offshore in Antigua or elsewhere in the Caribbean and other sites across the world.

speech.para: I am not sure what the government thinks it will achieve by this; it simply will not stop gambling on the Internet. I challenge any member of the government to come in here and explain to me—and to the House and to the Australian community—how they intend that this legislation will prevent Australians from gambling on the Internet. The answer, of course, is that they cannot give such an explanation. The government has not taken a rational approach to what are the real problems and the real concerns about the question of gambling. It has not ensured that we have a highly regulated and properly regulated Internet gambling industry—and I know that those involved in the industry have no problem with being regulated. If you had a mind to do so, you could even regulate to the extent of ensuring that they would not accept Australian based waging. That could be done very easily. Why you would do it, I have no idea, because of course they could still gamble from Antigua or elsewhere. You do not have to be Einstein to work this out—but, clearly, the Prime Minister is not Einstein, as we all know.

I note from the Senate committee that our Labor colleagues in their minority report said, in relation to this question of problem gambling, that the InterChurch Gambling Taskforce—whose submissions support the legislation which the government has put forward—acknowledged that it was more an expression of values than a solution to a potential problem. That is what it is. So why are we here effectively moving Australian jobs offshore? Why are we denying ourselves the possibility of properly regulating new Internet gaming operations that are based in Australia? Let me make it clear that this view that these things will not move offshore needs to be brought home. I am advised by Peter Bridge, the boss of Lasseters Casino in Alice Springs, Central Australia, that as a result of domestic prohibition there are already examples of casino operations moving to offshore jurisdictions with low standards of regulation. The example he uses is the Christchurch Casino. That casino has recently established Kiwicasino.com under a licence from Antigua, because of New Zealand's policy on online gambling.

Let us be very clear also: I am advised also that, in relation to the immediate impact of this legislation on operators in Australia, Federal Hotels in Tasmania have said that they will be taking down their Southern Cross casino site on Friday of this week, in order to comply with the government's requirements of a moratorium dating back to last May. What sort of absurdity is that?

As any observer of this place would know, I am not a great ally or fan of the Northern Territory government. Indeed, there would be very few occasions when I could see us walking on the same side of the street, let alone holding hands. But, on this issue, I share its view—a view which I understand not to be shared by the CLP senator from the Northern Territory who sits with the National Party who, when the vote was taken in the Senate last night, went missing, abstained, took a pair. Of course, the impact of that pair was to deny a Labor person, an opposition person, the opportunity to oppose it in the chamber while he squibbed it outside. He was not prepared to speak up for the people of the Northern Territory, not prepared to speak up and face the concerns of his own CL Party in the Northern Territory, not prepared to own up that he is so inept that he could not persuade the Prime Minister, his party room or the coalition of the potential impact of this legislation on the Northern Territory community. He was not prepared to take it up to the Prime Minister in terms of the concerns expressed by the CLP government in the Northern Territory about the ridiculous nature of this piece of legislation. He squibbed it. I would not have expected anything else from the bloke, to be very honest. After all, this is the second occasion in the last week where we have seen the Northern Territory done unceremoniously in the eye by John Howard's government.

I note that the shadow minister for transport is sitting at the table. As he will observe, and as I am sure I have mentioned to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, the first example occurred with road funding. I am advised that under normal circumstances the Northern Territory could expect to receive from the Commonwealth around 3.2 per cent of the allocation of these sorts of funds from the total bucket. In this instance, are you surprised to learn, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we received only 1.6 per cent, that we received only $20 million, and that the electorate of Gwydir, which is one-tenth the size of the Northern Territory and has a population only two-thirds that of the Northern Territory got $42 million—twice the amount of the Northern Territory? Of course the member for Gwydir is the Deputy Prime Minister. And what did the CLP senator for the Northern Territory do about that? He did absolutely nothing—as he did nothing about this except to walk out of the chamber when he could have taken the opportunity to express his view. Let us accept that he might have had to vote with the government. Why could he not have expressed his opposition to it? He could have accepted the discipline of the vote, but he could have got up and shown enough guts to express his opposition to this piece of legislation because of its impact on the Northern Territory community.

This legislation will not stop problem gamblers from betting online, that is clear, and anyone with any understanding or appreciation of this interactive communications media will tell you that. It will not stop Australian punters being ripped off or having their personal details misused. In fact, if they go to offshore sites as a result of this legislation, it is more than likely that that will happen than if they are working with regulated sides in Australia. It will not address issues such as problem gambling, domestic violence or family breakdown. If the government have a real concern about the impact of gambling on Australian families, why have they not been able to persuade state and territory governments to do something about poker machines? I share the view—probably a conservative view in some circles—that poker machines have done great harm to many Australians, to their families and to their lives. We know all about that. This bill will not help that. This bill will not help the problem punters who go down to the TAB every day or every week or who front up at the races to bet on course and do the week's wages. It will not help them. It will not provide harm minimisation or consumer protection. We can, however, provide consumer protection. We can do that by ensuring a quality gaming product, by having financial probity checks on providers and their staff, by maintaining the integrity of the games and the proper working of gaming equipment. That can be done. Instead of adopting that course, this government have closed their eyes to the reality—something to which they are blinded—that interactive gambling will continue into the future despite what this government does. Frankly, I think it is grossly irresponsible of the government to do what they are doing. To hear Senator Brown in the Senate carry on about the importance of excluding racing and gaming from this bill for some concocted reason is I think a very good indicator of what is fundamentally wrong with this legislation. It is opportunistic; it will not work. It is inherently contradictory and, as I said at the outset, it is fundamentally hypocritical.

I think all of us in this chamber would accept the view that we have to ensure that we do not have criminal activity linked to gambling. We should be making every possible effort to ensure that that is the case. We should do all we possibly can to stop money laundering through gambling activities. One of the best possible ways of doing that is by ensuring that we have proper regulations and controls over interactive gambling. It can be done. It is far more manageable than trying to monitor every punter who bets with a bookie at the races on a Saturday. You have to have ID, you have to have approved credit and you have to have your bank details. You and I can go to a bookie flashing 10 bucks and that is it, the bet is on—no problem. But does this bill do anything about that? Absolutely not. Instead of trying to structure a properly regulated environment for interactive gambling, this bill abdicates that responsibility.

Any understanding of where we are in technology development must lead you to realise that some time in the near future, with online digital communications rapidly emerging into the home, people are going to be able to sit in front of their televisions with their remote controls and literally plug into one of these sites in Antigua. What is the government going to do about that? Is it going to have the digital police monitoring households, jumping through bedroom windows to see what people are doing on their TVs? `Don't gamble, son'—

talk.start.para: —They did it to Laurie Brereton.

—That is right. Are we going to have a plethora of coppers merging into the community with their trench coats and caps, coming into our houses and saying: `Are you gambling? What have you got on the screen?' Perhaps it will be John Howard in disguise.
(Mr Nehl)—No, it might be the Prime Minister, but not—

—Well, there could be many John Howards, but in this case the Prime Minister. Will he be meandering up the street, swapping from side to side, knocking on doors—`Excuse me; gambling today, are we?' Or is he going to go to the racecourse, stand in front of the bookie circle and say, `Excuse me. What's your name? Bill Smith, is it? I notice you are in debt. You can't bet today'? I think not. It is okay for Kerry. `No problem, Kerry. You can go and spend millions offshore. We don't mind, Kerry. You can do that. No problem.' If you happen to be a person who is sitting at home, who has the wits to be able to use an interactive device, and you want to put a bet on, say at a casino in Australia, you cannot do it. But if you want to put a bet on at a casino in Antigua, you can do it.

speech.para: It seems to me that that is not too bright. Apart from the loss to the Australian community of the revenue which it is demonstrated is being secured from the taxation that flows from the gambling industry, apart from the jobs the industry is providing, apart from the window to e-commerce that it gives us, apart from the fact that we are developing world best technology to control gambling, the government says, `We are not interested. Give up. We are going to put a ban on.' You and I know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that bans do not work. Bans have not worked. We all know about prohibition. It did not work in the 1920s and 1930s and it will not work now. What you need is a properly regulated environment where interactive gambling is properly controlled. For that reason, I urge the House to support the position adopted by the Labor Party and, in particular, the amendment it has moved today.

talk.start.para: —As legislators, we are regularly called upon to consider issues of public importance for which there can be a more than respectable argument in favour or against a particular position. So it is with some caution that I speak in favour of the Interactive Gambling (Moratorium) Bill 2000. This is not to deny the good intentions of the bill and of those who drafted it, for problem gambling is a blight on our society, that extends beyond the problem gambler as an individual to their family and to their community. But it is not hypocrisy to recognise a social problem that requires a public policy response.

speech.para: There is no question that the increase in gambling options that has clearly taken place in Australia in the past decade has had externalities beyond the simple relationship between the gambler and the house. One does not need to examine laboriously the evidence collated by the Productivity Commission in its very thoughtful 1999 report to understand the magnitude of gambling as a modern industry. For the record, the commission found that 290,000 Australians, or over two per cent of the entire population, exhibited gambling behaviour that could be described as problematic.

One does not need to visit the gambling counsellors and group help organisations catering to gamblers seeking an end to their addiction to understand the impact that a gambling problem can have on an individual's life or on the life of their family. One does not have to survey a casino floor at four in the morning to accurately gauge the obsession that can overcome a gambler as they make their last play, not for winnings, but for that which they have already lost. One does not need to visit too many pubs or clubs in Sydney or Melbourne or Adelaide to understand the devastating effect of the poker machine on social interaction, on live music or on the simple act of having a drink after work.

Yet the act of gambling is an act of free will. Once we begin denying citizens the right to govern their own lives—regardless, it must be said, of whether they wish to deprive themselves of their own free will—we enter the murky waters of soft tyranny. Thankfully, that is not what this bill proposes, contrary to its, perhaps more hysterical, critics. In its amended form—amended, that is, since its defeat in the Senate in October—it is more appropriately crafted. It will now exempt from the scope of the moratorium wagering services equivalent to those offered off-line on 19 May 2000 and in traditional wagering formats; services that relate to betting on an outcome of a sporting event where the bets are placed, made, received or accepted after the beginning of the event; and services that relate to betting on a contingency that may or may not happen in the course of a sporting event where the bets are placed, made, received or accepted after the beginning of an event.

The proposed exemption will not permit the introduction of more interactive ball by ball style microwagering. Furthermore, new wagering services will not be permitted during the period of the moratorium. As almost every speaker on this bill to date, for or against, has noted, gambling in Australia is seen as part of our national culture. Be it by lottery, by wager or by chance, Australians are active participants in the gambling culture. As legislators, we may have personal likes and dislikes when it comes to specific games or wagers but we recognise generally that, like drinking and like fine food, gambling, taken in moderation, is not detrimental to one's health. I am pleased to note that this bill recognises that fact. It does not seek to ban gambling or even to reduce gambling; rather, it is a moratorium on a specific sector of the gambling industry, a breathing space for the community to engage in thoughtful public policy.

Similar philosophical issues dominated my consideration of the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Online Services) Bill 1999. In that debate, my support was drawn to the legislation by the notion of equivalency—that is, I did not believe that, simply by virtue of it being offered on a new medium, Australian material published on the Internet ought to have been legally immune from Australian classification law. I believe that the moratorium in this bill is also justified by the notion of equivalency in public policy.

Gambling in Australia has come to be regulated and guided by public policy development over decades—in fact, over two centuries. Often that policy development, conducted by the states and territories and by their colonial precursors, was a case of one step forwards and two steps back. The accommodation of offcourse betting in an illegal but tolerated form is a good example of that haphazard development. Nonetheless, the opportunity to develop those regulations and guidelines was conducive to the more appropriate development of a legal gambling industry. The very example of SP bookmaking's reform is testament to the value of that opportunity. We may not have decades or even years to develop a similar regulatory response to online gambling, but this moratorium does offer us 12 months from 19 May 2000 to develop an appropriate response.

Just as this parliament was not convinced that the particular technological nature of the Internet exempted material published on the Internet from Australian law, so this parliament ought not to be convinced that the technological nature of online gambling should exempt it from careful and considered regulatory development, especially in relation to the obvious externalities associated with problem gambling and under-age gambling. In making this case, I may be at some variance with supporters of this bill who have spoken in the other place. But I do say in response to the member for Melbourne Ports that being a Liberal does not mean being a libertine. Liberals support the appropriate regulation of gambling generally. Why should Liberals not also support the consideration of the appropriate regulation of online gambling?

Some supporters of the moratorium have applauded its introduction as an opportunity to garner the evidence to condemn online gambling in its entirety—to make it online but offshore. I am sceptical about whether adult Australian Internet users should be denied the opportunity to gamble online, and I am very sceptical as to whether such a ban is possible. In a free society, the burden of proof lies with those who would deny freedoms to others. But this moratorium gives both proponents and opponents the opportunity to put their arguments to the Australian people and to the Australian government, and it gives the people and the government the time to properly consider the future regulation of this sector of the gambling industry.

In this regard, I note that the National Office for the Information Economy, in consultation with the Treasury, the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Family and Community Services, is presently finalising a study into the feasibility and consequences of the ban. I urge all members of this House and the executive to consider the findings of the report of the National Office for the Information Economy with an open mind and without a predisposed position on such a ban. As such, I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Interactive Gambling (Moratorium) Bill 2000. I have some grave concerns about the opportunities and the dangers that are presented by online gambling. I am a person who believes in people being responsible for their own activities and the way they live their lives. I believe in taking the responsibility that all people, given the wonderful rights and freedoms that we enjoy in this country, should exercise when we set about conducting ourselves in the community. In other words, I believe we all have rights and responsibilities. I think that is engrained in this government's philosophy and the way it looks at policy and endeavours to chart the way ahead. With that in mind, I do have grave concerns about the way in which online gambling can work and the way in which it is being approached, particularly by members opposite.

speech.para: One of the things that I think has been distributed to the House is the proposed amendment by the opposition. I had a good, close read of that amendment, but to be frank I believe it is not worthy of consideration. I think it is little more than rhetoric and does not contribute at all to the central problem that the government is trying to address—I might say, with the broad support of many Australians.

I would like to turn to a few of the things that the members opposite said. Before I do that, I would like to conjure up in members' minds the way in which online gambling allows people to enjoy gambling. It would be available if you do have a computer and you are able to go online or, as the member for the Northern Territory said, it would be available through the television. You can click on your TV or you can use your computer. You can do this in the privacy of your own home and you can use your own credit card for the gambling part of the operation. In doing so, you can—I presume—take that credit card to the max in the security and the privacy of your own home, with no-one watching.

Most of the members of this House and most of Australian society have the real capacity to manage that kind of thing. Anyone realises the danger and that, if you take your credit card to the max in half an hour in a splurge on the gambling machines, the consequences for you are quite horrendous. You are going to have to pay all that back. So you would, no doubt, be very judicious in the use of such a pleasure, in doing this sort of thing in your own home. But there are people without the kind of restraint, when it comes to gambling, that ordinary people in the community exhibit. Some of those people are physically addicted to gambling and do respond, even when they are required to go to a public place, when they are in the bar of a hotel where there are poker machines or when they are in a casino. They cannot restrain themselves there and, let me tell you, when they are in the privacy of their own home, with no-one watching and with no-one looking over their shoulder and tut-tutting at their behaviour, or when the possibility of the shame of spending all next week's rent in a splurge on the machines is not going to be known to anyone but themselves, the threat of this kind of behaviour is there and it is all the more obvious the more you think about it.

Members opposite are chiding the government about putting in place this moratorium and taking steps to curtail gambling—and, of course, that is not directly the objective of this legislation; this legislation is about giving time to consider a reasoned response. Members opposite are chiding the government, saying: `It's too hard. The government should be rolling over and going ahead with it.' They say that, if we do not, it will go on in places like Antigua; it will be a source of money for small economies in the Caribbean. `Why shouldn't Australia,' they say, `enjoy that bonanza?' In fact, I could not believe the attitude of the member for Melbourne Ports. He regards this as one of the few areas of the dot com economy that return consistent profits. He suggested that, as a result, there would be high wage jobs and high-tech jobs from a machine that probably plays a little bit of music, produces a row of cards and says: `Too bad. You've just lost your rent money.' Those are the kinds of high-tech jobs that members opposite want.

They are chiding the government. They are saying that all this would go on in Antigua. They are asking: why don't we join them on the descent into hell? Why don't we facilitate these kinds of high-tech jobs? Why don't we set out after this part of the dot com economy that can make consistent profits? The member for Melbourne Ports has the gall to accuse the government of having very little moral compass or few core values, when members opposite are standing up one after the other proposing this kind of radical expansion of people's capability to access gambling. They are out there proposing that, without a thought to what impact that might have, and they are standing up one after the other and criticising poker machines when you can, in effect, gamble so much more heavily in the privacy of your own home, without anyone watching, and the only time you are going to get caught out is when the house is taken out from under you, and your wife and children are turned out into the streets.

I am not a fan of gambling. As the member for Curtin said, it can be enjoyed in moderation. I agree with that. I also agree with 70 per cent of Australian people, who say that gambling does more harm than good. Those are the findings of the recent report that has been considered here on numerous occasions. Some 70 per cent of people believe gambling does more harm than good, and I believe they are very perceptive. Some 92 per cent of people do not want to see more poker machines in Australia. If 92 per cent of people do not want to see more poker machines, when they get a load of the way this system works, more than 92 per cent of people will be saying that they do not want this.

I can understand the attitude of the member for the Northern Territory, for example. The member for the Northern Territory mentioned Lasseters Casino in Alice Springs. He said that Lasseters Casino has a turnover of $210 million and that it has 85,000 players playing its games. Without having made the switch to this kind of online gambling, I believe Lasseters Casino would be broke. I believe that this system has saved its bacon. There was a hotel attached to Lasseters Casino in Alice Springs. It has been shut up for years. It has not had any guests in it. It has been shut up because it had financial difficulties. I believe Lasseters Casino has switched to this lucrative form of earning income because it sees a dollar to be made, and I believe members opposite see a dollar to be made and I believe they see it in relation to the states in particular.

I note that subclause (f) of the second part of the opposition's second reading amendment says that the government should be addressing revenue issues that impact upon state government decisions relating to interactive gambling. I can tell you that in Queensland, without the government's goods and services tax, gambling has become a de facto growth tax. Gambling has become one of the major sources of revenue driving schools, hospitals and police. Isn't it bizarre that, in Australia today, we have to gamble to fund schools? That is the way it is in Queensland today: to fund schools, you have got to gamble; to fix roads, you have got to gamble. There are problems and distortions in the tax system in Queensland when that kind of a regime applies. I do not believe that we can fix the problem by giving gamblers more of the drug that they apparently crave. We do not fix it by turning them on a little bit more, by giving them more of a kick out of gambling—which every member in this place knows is a real social problem.

I am sure that every member in this House has had people in their electorates ruined by gambling. The members opposite can squawk all they like that poker machines are the great evil but online gambling, because it is high tech, is somehow pure. They seem to want to draw some kind of moral boundary between one and the other. If you ask me, online gambling is worse. If you can do these things without having to consult your conscience at all—in other words, if you can curl up under your doona and blow your rent cheque—I think that is a far worse and more dangerous proposition for Australian society than all of the poker machines and casinos that we currently have. It is much worse.

One of the great faults in what the opposition are proposing, with Antigua and this trumped-up argument they are pushing, is that there would be gambling in Antigua anyway. What they want to do, they say, is to legitimise it. They want to give it a lovely saccharine sugar coating and establish a regime in Australia that protects gamblers. They call it harm minimisation. So if you are dealing with an Australian company when you are curled up under your doona—a high-tech dot com gambling company—you will be secure. If you ever happen to make a winning in that process, it would be protected. Isn't that great? What a great service they are providing to the Australian economy by proposing that. All of those people, when they are under their doonas, will feel a lot more secure about blowing their rent cheques.

I am sure even Kerry Packer would tell everyone that while gambling does occasionally produce a return, it costs very dearly. Any fan of gambling would tell them that that is the situation. Yet the members opposite want to legitimise it and make it part of a protected situation. I would much rather that some concerns be raised in the minds of people when they set about accessing interactive gambling. I would rather that they had to think twice, before they put the rent cheque on the line, about whether or not there might be an outcome at the other end. If you had to deal with Antigua or Tajikistan through your modem with your rent cheque, you might think twice and stick your rent cheque back in the bank, or you might actually go and pay your rent with it. But these are the kinds of people I am worried about. The members opposite want to facilitate their gambling habit. The cost of that kind of behaviour is horrendous. There are 130,000 Australians with severe gambling problems, and they lose an average of $12,000 each—$3.5 billion in total. You could argue, as members opposite would, that that is $3.5 billion, potentially, to go into the wonderful, high-tech economy. `Wow!' they say. `What a wonderful opportunity for Australia!' I say: that is $3.5 billion on our welfare bill, basically. That is money that is going to have to be paid by welfare agencies and charitable organisations that should be, I think, dealing with government and parliamentary representatives who want to see their burden minimised, not racked up because of some fixation that the member for Melbourne Ports has with the dot com economy. The member for Melbourne Ports said that by proceeding with this kind of thing we would be pursuing the knowledge nation. One thing I know is: if you gamble, you are going to lose. If that is his example of the knowledge nation, then it is something we really ought to be very concerned about.

The member also spoke about the Liberal Party and its structure. I know that in Queensland the structure of the Labor Party has ensured that there were interactive gaming licences granted to an organisation called GOCORP. Who were the people associated with GOCORP? A bunch of Labor mates. I think subsequent events have illustrated the background of some of those Labor mates. Obviously, an interactive gaming licence involves someone of the stature of Bill D'Arcy, who is today in jail. Charges were already laid against him when that gaming licence was being granted in Queensland.

Members opposite talk about this process of granting licences to Australian companies as a possible way to reduce criminal involvement. I would like them to look at that example. I would like them to consider what that means. What was the level of scrutiny given to that particular transaction? What effort went into that? What guarantee was there that the knowledge nation would benefit by that proposal?

talk.start.para: —You mean it didn't suffer the brown paper bag test.

—It is much worse than the brown paper bag test; it is, I think, a situation that Australians would be horrified about. If we were to deal with gaming licences all over Australia in the carefree way that the Queensland government did on that occasion, we would—if you regard problem gamblers and their difficulties as being a contagion—be dealing with a bunch of people hell-bent on spreading that contagion by encouraging people to take up gambling and encouraging the worst types of irresponsible gambling activity.

speech.para: In closing, I have to say that on occasions I go to the races, on occasions I buy a lotto ticket and on occasions I go down to the local club and play the pokie machines for maybe 15 minutes. I do not find it an unpleasant form of behaviour—you can enjoy yourself doing that. I think many Australian families and other people have a greater love of gambling than I do, and for these people the whole of the gambling industry is providing an excellent service. I think that as a society what we must worry about are those who are hooked on this activity and are not responding appropriately to it. When the government considers its position as a result of this moratorium and looks to the way ahead, we must consider ordinary Australian families and the fact that each Australian loves a punt and should have the opportunity to enjoy it. But at the same time we must make sure that we do not facilitate an explosion in problem gambling by supporting it and fostering its continuance. (Time expired).

talk.start.para: — I rise today to speak on the Interactive Gambling (Moratorium) Bill 2000. It is one that I personally support. I think it is appropriate that we have this legislation in the House. It is unfortunate that previous legislation was knocked back in the upper house and that there have been some amendments. But I think it is appropriate that we now see this bill go forward. The reality is that the Democrats have said that it is not a serious bill. Given the impact of gambling on the lives of everyday Australians I believe it is a very serious bill. It is appropriate that we have a one-year moratorium on Internet interactive gambling so that we can consider the consequences of this leap forward.

speech.para: I have an interest in this area because of personal experience. For a number of years I was the shadow minister for finance in New South Wales and I also used to act as shadow Treasurer in New South Wales. During the time that I was shadow minister a bill was introduced which legalised draw poker machines in hotels. It was to be on a limited basis and was expected to have minor consequences for clubs. It was to assist hotels remain viable and was to be a minor adjunct to their activities. More than a decade later we can see the impact of that legislation. We have seen a proliferation of these draw poker machines in hotels throughout New South Wales and the hotels depend for their livelihood on them. The volume of money from poker machines runs into multimillions per hotel, further expanding the overall area of activity. When people looked at it at that stage it was seen as being fairly benign. It is a different situation now, given the degree of competition in the gambling market between the clubs and the number of poker machines that exist in hotels. We have that very situation here: Internet gambling is exploding. People want to participate in interactive gambling. I think the minister concerned and the government should be commended for calling for this moratorium. It is a disgrace that it was knocked back before.

This is a serious situation and the impact on people's lives is very significant. Again, I speak from my own experience. The solicitor I was dealing with when I was purchasing a house suddenly advised me that he was handing over his practice to another solicitor. He was subsequently put in jail for gambling and losing his life's earnings. He lost his practice, and the funds people had invested with him, because he had a gambling addiction. For a lot of people gambling is a fine social activity that has no negative consequences but a proportion of the population do become gambling addicts, and it is that aspect of it that we are concerned about. We do not want to go blindly into interactive gambling. As the shadow minister would know—his expertise in the technology and Internet areas is appropriate—approximately 50 per cent of Australian households have access through the Internet to gambling. Because people have that widespread access, instead of having to walk down to a TAB, club or hotel to play poker machines they can pull up a chair, sit in their own living room and take the action.

So that is the reason for it. In fact, if you look at the extent to which Australians are involved in gambling, we are amongst the leaders in the world. In the United States they have gambling in places like Las Vegas, Atlantic City and Nevada but, basically, it is confined to those areas. We have gambling places everywhere. I think that 20 per cent of all poker machines in the world are located in Australia. It is estimated that some 300,000 gamblers in Australia have a serious problem. These are the people who lose over $12,000 per year each. If we think of the average wage of an Australian then we can see that they are gambling away almost half of average income every year. There are consequences for families and children in those relationships, and for the activities that gamblers get involved in as a result of that gambling addiction. It is quite a tragedy. It often leads to marriage breakdowns, violence, depression and countless other problems. So it is important to be aware of the social consequences of gambling.

Remember that we had an inquiry in New South Wales before the casino was introduced there. Sir Laurence Street headed up an inquiry to look at the social consequences of the casino. The report came out saying that there would be a few problems but they could be handled with counselling. Again, we have had extensive problems through the widespread use of casinos throughout Australia, as each state's capital city had to have their own casino as they vied for the gambling dollar and brought in the high spenders from overseas. The consequences we have seen, just in terms of families, from those decisions are significant. We should not downplay the social consequences of gambling. I was very pleased to see that, two years ago, overwhelming public concern about this issue prompted the government to request a Productivity Commission inquiry into the issue. It showed that, if losses are averaged out across the nation, each adult in Australia loses around $800 per year. So this is about not sitting around and saying, `It's all too hard; the years of the Internet are here—let's just let the free market determine it.' I am very much a free market person but there are obviously areas of market failure and, where we have significant social consequences, we should look at those areas.

The bill calls for a one-year moratorium, that is, it prohibits the use of interactive gambling services that were not provided before 19 May this year for one year. Exemptions are provided in the case where an operator has provided that service before 19 May and was under the same name prior to that date. The reason for this one-year moratorium is that it will give the government a chance to review its legislative options in an area which is growing far quicker than is presently possible to control through the law. I was very interested to see that Senator Ellison said in his second reading speech:

quote.para: ... the inertia and the revenue generated by a large and established industry is overwhelming. The Commonwealth is determined not to repeat this mistake with interactive gambling.

speech.para: As a further illustration of what Senator Ellison was saying, when New South Wales introduced poker machines in pubs five years ago the revenue lifted from $7 billion a year to $11 billion in just four years—a rate of $1 billion per year increase.

The penalty imposed by the bill is significant— 2,000 penalty points for each day the offence has been committed. That is $220,000 per day maximum for individuals and $1.1 million maximum for corporations. It will come in when this legislation receives royal assent. There have been proposals for amendments regarding wagering services that relate to betting on an outcome of a sporting event when the bets are placed after the beginning of the event, or when bets are placed on some event that could happen during the course of an event when the bets are placed after the event has begun. They will still be allowed. This is because such bets were already occurring over the telephone and by other means. The exemptions from the moratorium should not reduce the effectiveness of this legislation. The exemptions the government has proposed will not, however, allow the increasingly common ball-by-ball type of interactive gambling—and neither they should. In other words, the bill will not allow a gambler to be constantly betting through the Internet on what will happen on the next ball of today's Prime Minister's XI game—for which we certainly wish the Australians well. This provision is obviously a sensible one as it is interactive forms of gambling like this which can turn average punters into problem gamblers.

I conclude by noting that the government is expecting to receive the report of the National Office of the Information Economy on this matter in the very near future. The government has worked with a number of departments, including the Treasury and the Department of Family and Community Services, to analyse the options and possible outcomes of a ban on Internet gambling. No final decision has been made, but I certainly commend the minister and the government on this decision. This decision shows that we are not going to rush headlong into interactive gambling without considering the social consequences of poker machines and casinos. The expansion of poker machines into hotels has had a serious downturn in terms of the social consequences right throughout Australia. The devastation of families, of partners and children of those with gambling addiction, the impact on companies and other secondary impacts of gambling have been seen. I am sure that all of us would not want to try to provide strict controls on gambling but, in terms of the social consequences, we in this place have a responsibility to consider the wider impact in Australia. On behalf of my colleagues, I commend this legislation to the House.

talk.start.para: —I support the comments made by the member for Cook in relation to the leadership shown by the government through the Interactive Gambling (Moratorium) Bill 2000 in the way the government has proactively looked at changing technology and the vast array of options that are becoming increasingly available in all forms of our lifestyle. In that sense, I certainly support what has been put to the parliament today. The bill aims to halt the further expansion of interactive gambling in Australia for 12 months from 19 May 2000 while the government investigates the feasibility and consequences of actually banning interactive gambling. It is a breathing space, and a sensible breathing space.

speech.para: As members on both sides of the House would be aware, the Internet gambling industry is growing rapidly. The government recognises that we need to take immediate action to halt this as it poses a serious threat to compulsive, problematic gamblers, their families and indeed our community. I am concerned that this new interactive gambling technology has the ability to provide access to gambling like we have never seen before. Interactive technology just brings gambling into the home in a way that we have certainly not seen. It is just so easy these days if it is on your computer screen, you have a credit card and you are a compulsive gambler. Before you know it, you are in deep strife. As members would be aware, the Howard government is concerned that, with this unprecedented possible access and the attraction of these services, the youth and the vulnerable could be attracted like never before, creating a new wave of problem gamblers.

It has been only in the past decade that my state of Queensland has had poker machines. With their introduction, we saw immediately people flocking to have a punt, and there is nothing wrong with that. In some cases, though, it was more than just a punt; it became a way of life. Day after day at home, at 10 o'clock in the morning, just before they open, I see people queuing up outside the establishments that have poker machines, wanting to get in to get on the poker machines. I think that is quite sad. We need to take action now because of these wider possibilities that are available that could so easily get out of control.

We cannot repeal the mistakes of the past, where we now see poker machines in basically every pub and club, generating a lot of dollars for consolidated revenue but costing families so dearly. There is a bit of an enigma here, where state governments which take all of this revenue out of the gambling industry are not so happy about this federal government legislation, and I wonder why that might be. I wonder if it might be because they might lose a further revenue stream that they would otherwise have. I ask the state governments particularly to have a think about the social consequences and their social responsibility in relation to the ever increasing takes from the gambling industry. It is important to note that gambling is not a sin. Many in my electorate of Herbert in Townsville and Thuringowa enjoy having a punt at the races or going down to Jupiters casino. However, as I said earlier, for some it is a serious problem, not just for the gambler but also for their family, their friends and our community.

Under this bill, it is an offence to provide an interactive gambling service in Australia. It is important to note that it is not a permanent ban but a temporary halt so we can work out ways to make sure that it will not harm our community in the long run. But it does have some sensible exemptions. For example, if it can be shown that the service is the same or substantially the same as a pre 19 May service, uses the same name as that service and had at least one genuine paying customer prior to that date, there will be an exemption for that service. The bill prevents new entrants from establishing services during the period of the moratorium and constrains existing providers from introducing new services to take advantage of their privileged market position. That is sensible. It specifically exempts phone betting and services relating to certain futures and options contracts. Online share trading—which has just been a revolution in how that has developed—online insurance policy applications and other risk bearing financial transactions are clearly not gambling, although some might say they are. I think people would understand that they, too, will be exempted, as the bill makes clear. The Corporations Law already recognises this and specifically exempts these contracts from being subject to gambling laws. In order to remain consistent with the Corporations Law and to remove any doubt about the type of service this moratorium is intended to cover, the government has decided to make it clear that these contracts, particularly the futures and options contracts, are not subject to the moratorium.

It is important to remember that the bill focuses on businesses providing gambling because the government does not intend the moratorium to affect the not-for-profits who run their own fundraising activities. We have them in all sorts of ways in our electorates, but they can be there electronically as well, and this bill does not affect that. It does not affect private, friendly bets or other non-commercial betting, such as office tipping pools. In Townsville, Roberts Nehmer Mckee, a local firm of lawyers, is running a tipping competition on the Crocodiles basketball club. My prediction is that the Crocodiles will win the National Basketball League this year, beating the Adelaide 36ers if all goes well. Of course, there are tipping pools on NRL football games as well, and they are exempted from this kind of moratorium.

I support the bill because it protects the vulnerable and the young. As we are all aware, young people are really up with the latest computer technology, and if they have a credit card and a computer and see an opportunity while on the Internet, there is a possibility that that credit card may be worn out within an hour. Reports have proved that problem gamblers established their addiction in their youth, so I guess that makes this point doubly important. It has already been proved that young people outnumber others as participants in online gambling.

I noted that, in the Senate last week, Labor Senator Kate Lundy spoke about harm minimisation and government inaction about other forms of gambling. One must ask: is Senator Lundy aware that the federal government does not have jurisdiction in relation to other forms of gambling? She then spoke about the need for harm minimisation. We can stop this before it becomes a major problem. I believe Senator Chapman said it perfectly when contradicting Senator Lundy's remarks when he said:

quote.para: We ... believe in harm prevention, not harm minimisation.

speech.para: I receive many calls in my electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker—and I assume that you might too—from concerned parents, churches and other community groups about this issue. I receive calls from people saying that it is an invasion of civil liberties, but I think we all share a common theme: that this parliament must do something to ensure that online gambling does not turn into a major social problem.

The temptation for the states to ignore the issue is high, as the inertia and the revenue generated by a large and established industry are very compelling indeed. However, we must take the lead. Suggesting that we must take the lead is about where I came into this debate, and taking the lead is something we are doing. We are doing it for the community and we are doing it for our kids. There are significant penalties in the bill and that detail has been explained already.

Finally, some people say that such a moratorium or ban is not possible. Some people say that it is not feasible. They say that the Internet has no boundaries and that it is global. I disagree. I believe that, if we work together, and if we have an effective approach, a ban on Internet gambling on Australian sites is certainly possible. I support the bill and I support the prospect of a cooling-off period. And I particularly support the bill because I do not want to see the kids of Australia sitting at a computer, pushing a button and, for example, making a bet on who the next President of the United States might be.

talk.start.para: —I have been an Independent since April this year. I have supported the Labor Party on most bills and, when I have not, I have abstained, and that is because I share the same philosophical base as the Labor Party. But I want to indicate that, in relation to the Interactive Gambling (Moratorium) Bill 2000, I will be supporting the government. The reason I have made that decision is that I do not believe, firstly, that there is anything in traditional Labor philosophy which supports the position that the Labor Party is taking at the moment in relation to this bill, and certainly there is nothing inconsistent with me supporting the position of a moratorium which is inconsistent with traditional Labor philosophy.

speech.para: Let me explain what my concerns are. The tremendous social problem that Australia has in relation to gambling has already been mentioned in this House and in the Senate. This social problem is exploding. It is extremely serious, and it is impacting on, very often, the most disadvantaged people in our community. Certainly, it is impacting very heavily and disproportionately on a constituency that I have purported to represent over the years in parliament—I am referring to the ethnic communities.

The expansion of gambling in Victoria, for example, has lead, you can say, to a major crisis in the Australian Chinese community in Melbourne, stemming from the massive expansion of gambling through the development of the casino, the development of poker machines in pubs and many other such developments. It would be wrong for us to further expand these gambling opportunities and not to show the way in terms of saying, `Look, as legislators, as parliamentarians, we believe that it is time'—at least, symbolically, and not only symbolically but also I think this legislation has teeth, which I will refer to later—`to indicate that this matter has gone too far.' That is what I believe. I believe that the gambling disease has infiltrated the nation to a huge extent and to an extent which is not healthy. The level of gambling in Australia is one of the highest in world.

I referred before to the Chinese community, but that is not the only community that is being affected by gambling. There is a whole range of migrant and ethnic communities that has been, in a sense—for whatever cultural reasons—drawn into this gambling fever, and the social consequences have been devastating. First of all, the statistics are covered up but are you aware of the number of people who actually commit suicide as a result of their gambling debts? Of course this is not recorded, but we know that they even had to put special cameras in the toilets at the Crown Casino in Melbourne in order to try to prevent people, who were so desperate and had reached such a level of desperation in their gambling, killing themselves. But, leaving aside that extreme, what about the number of marriage breakdowns? What about the number of people who have lost not only some of their property, some of their income and some of their assets but even their own home, the place that they live in? And we are not talking here about one isolated individual in the sense of one single person; we are talking about whole families devastated by this phenomenon.

The previous state Labor government put legislation in place to introduce poker machines in Victoria. This was gleefully adopted by Premier Kennett and a massive expansion of poker machines occurred throughout the state of Victoria. One of the major areas in which this expansion occurred was in the disadvantaged suburbs in the north and west of Melbourne, where there are many poor people. Those areas had the biggest expansion of poker machines. We had the pathetic situation of pensioners who have no other income but the pension receiving their pension and, within hours, losing all of it on poker machines.

These are serious social problems. Not only should the economic dimension of the matter be considered but the social culture of Australia has been changed by this massive expansion of gambling. The social interactions that used to occur in pubs, for example, no longer occur. People go to the pub, stand before the machine, spending hours there, and then when they have lost all their money go home. What happened to the tradition of social interaction in pubs and clubs? This is a change in the culture and it is a very poor change. I believe that we must act in relation to the problem of gambling, and I therefore support the moratorium.

If you want to hear the actual facts—for those of you who do not like anecdotal evidence—then read the report of the Productivity Commission as initiated by the Treasurer. The inquiry was undertaken by Gary Banks, the Chairman of the Productivity Commission, and Mr Robert Fitzgerald, who was President of the Australian Council of Social Service from 1993 to 1997. Some of the findings of the report are that 80 per cent of Australians gambled in the last year, spending about $11 billion, with 40 per cent gambling regularly, and that just over 290,000 people—and that is a conservative estimate—are problem gamblers, with 130,000 of these with severe problems. And you know what it means to be classified as having severe problems. Problem gamblers lose around $12,000 a year each and their total annual expenditure is around $3.5 billion.

The prevalence of problem gambling is related to the degree of accessibility to gambling, particularly gaming machines—and this gets back to the point I made about Victoria. But of course it is not just Victoria that has this problem: all the states now have a proliferation of gambling machines. One of the problems is that gaming machines have become an essential part of the revenue of state governments. They rely on that revenue and, therefore, whatever measures they try to take to rein in gaming machines are going to be half-hearted. The recently elected Bracks government is to be congratulated for having a go, but it is like trying to close the gate after the horse has bolted. The point has been made in this debate, by the way, that if the states had been more responsible at the time when there was such a proliferation of poker machines we may not have this level of problem—because, as the report says, accessibility is a major issue in relation to such machines.

Continuing with the conclusions of the Productivity Commission, 70 per cent of people surveyed believe that gambling did more harm than good and 92 per cent did not want to see a further expansion of gaming machines. Huge! The social costs of gambling were also commented on and these were seen as substantial. The estimates, of course, are difficult to identify but they range from a low of $1.8 billion to $5.6 billion. Although obviously there are some economic benefits to gambling, there are also these huge social costs, and not only do these social costs lead to a degradation of the spirit and culture of the nation but also these social costs have to be paid for.

Of course, we have had the Victorian Casino and Gaming Authority challenge the conclusions of the report and we have had a number of others trying to minimise the problem. But the problem is not able to be minimised—and I go back to the example that I gave. For all the data that we have already picked up, there are specific ethnic communities where the problem is even more serious than in the general community. You might say: if it is all out there and it is so bad, what is the point of trying to prevent something like this? The answer to that—and it is really a philosophical issue—is that if something is evil you do not compound the evil by allowing it to become even greater. You do not do that. You try to put into place measures which will minimise the evil. That, I maintain, is what we are faced with here.

It seems to me that the only way to get around this problem is to deal with the online gambling issue directly. I support a moratorium—after all, it is only a stopgap measure intended to prevent the expansion of these industries. Let us study the impact of online and interactive gambling on communities around the world, keeping in mind the propensity of Australians to become involved very quickly in all forms of new gambling. We can then come to some conclusions about the likely outcome of online gambling and decide whether we should introduce a ban, continue the moratorium for a time or allow some forms of gambling under a tightly regulated regime. However, at the moment I cannot see what harm a moratorium will do.

Online gambling requires a computer, and the government has expressed concern about the expansion of gambling at home. I agree with the government. I agree also with those Democrat senators and Senator Bob Brown who have expressed concern about this issue. I know that Mr Peter Andren is also worried about it. I refer the House to some interesting data in the paper, Current State of Play: Australia and the Information Economy , released by the National Office for the Information Economy. It shows that Internet access at home is likely to be much higher among couples with children than among single persons or those with no children. A November 1999 survey found that 39 per cent of couples with children had Internet access at home compared with 19 per cent of single parent families, 23 per cent of couples with no children, and 10 per cent of single persons. In other words, the potential use of gambling facilities is greater among couples with children.

A number of members who have spoken in this debate mentioned that all the psychological and sociological evidence shows that people catch the gambling habit early in life. So if children pick up this habit, a whole new group will get into gambling through the Internet. That is a grave concern. It is bad enough that many people got into gambling with the introduction of poker machines; now another group—many of whom have not been involved in the poker machine phenomenon—will be gambling online. That will create even more serious social problems.

I argue that we must tackle this problem. As I said, I have seen no persuasive arguments against introducing a moratorium. If, after an examination of the situation over the next 12 months, arguments are offered regarding the imposition of a restrictive regime, so be it. But at this stage I believe it is necessary to take some action to prevent the same kind of phenomenon that occurred with the state governments in relation to poker machines. Poker machines proliferated very quickly and, before the government could retrieve data about what was happening, many negative consequences emerged. State governments are now saying, `Well, we can do something to prevent the issuing of new licences.' However, there is a huge number of existing poker machines in Melbourne, Sydney and throughout Australia and they will continue to have devastating consequences. Why should we allow another form of gambling that will attract many people who are not substantially involved in the industry at present?

This is a big moral issue. One may ask: why should the government legislate to protect people from themselves? After all, people have freedom of choice. They can gamble. They do not have to go to a casino and they do not have to use poker machines—although it is a bit difficult to go to a pub nowadays and have nothing to do with poker machines, because they are everywhere. Almost all the traditional pubs have closed; most pubs have had to install poker machines in order to survive.

Let us consider a philosophical matter for a moment. Is this a civil liberties issue? No, it is not. The government and the parliament have a moral responsibility to show leadership in relation to these issues. That moral responsibility is not just symbolic: we must take concrete decisions to prevent these problems from occurring. Maybe the gambling industry in Australia can be rationalised and, in that context, we may be prepared to allow some forms of gambling. But my gut feeling at present is that interactive gambling will create massive social problems, including broken marriages and people living in poverty because they have lost everything, or nearly everything, as a result of gambling.

I am sorry that I have gone slightly over time but I wanted to make my views about this issue clear. I accept the general argument in favour of a moratorium, which I believe will achieve at least some good by slowing down the development of another bad social phenomenon. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I endorse everything that the member for Calwell has said. I note that, at the beginning of his speech, he was almost apologetic that he was voting with the government on this issue and felt as though he had to explain himself to his former Labor Party colleagues. I do not think that many of his former Labor Party colleagues would disagree with what he has said. But their handling of such issues stands in direct contrast with that of this side of the House where, although we might have different views on things, we are able to express them. I would say that what has happened over on that side of the House is that a couple of the leadership group have decided what the Labor Party's policy is going to be and, despite what anyone in the back bench thinks, that policy will be what the leaders say.

speech.para: You just have to look at the speakers list, Mr Deputy Speaker. If you look at the speakers list over the last few weeks, you will see that, where the opposition feels strongly or is to argue strongly about a bill, there are many speakers from that side. On today's speakers list, this particular bill is almost the only one where government members outnumber opposition members—and I would say that they are cowering in their offices saying, `Gee, I hope the government gets this up because we support it deeply.'

Gambling has played a recreational role in Australian society to such an extent that it is almost seen as a distinguishing feature of the national character. For evidence, we need look no further than our folkloric reputation for betting on two flies crawling up a wall and the integral role played by two-up in conjunction with the deeply significant Anzac Day remembrances. Therefore, we as a society do not view all gambling—nor do we view all gamblers—as undesirable, by definition. In addition to the considerable contribution made to government coffers by revenue raised from gambling, it could be argued that the activity has offered some social benefits: people have tended to congregate in clubs, where cheaper meals and entertainment have supplemented the availability of gambling; those clubs have also been bound to invest much of their revenue back into the community in the form of sponsorship for sporting clubs, for example.

This bill is not about tackling the problems that derive from poker machines or casino activities. It is about nipping in the bud an industry, which is still very much in its infancy, for a period of time in which we will be able to make some longer term judgments. If at the conclusion of the moratorium a ban is found not to be feasible and subsequently is not imposed, at the very least the government will urge the states and territories to enact a uniform national set of regulatory standards, formulated in consultation with the Commonwealth. That is all this is about. It is about having a breather, having a space to see whether we are just flying headlong into an area where we have seen so many problems develop.

It has been noted for many years that gambling is a vice—though not for everybody; it is a major problem for a large number of its participants, leading in the long term often to personal crises and family collapse. A colleague in the legal profession commented only recently on the increase in fraud cases he was representing—most often as a result of runaway gambling habits. So it stands to reason that any increase in marketing and availability of gambling should be viewed very warily, given the fact that it is already estimated that one out of every 50 Australians is a `problem gambler'. I repeat: one out of every 50 Australians is a `problem gambler'. Many of those may not even know it yet. They may not have been exposed to the situation where they will develop into problem gamblers. But regular participants in the gambling industry, almost one in seven of these people, suffer the consequences of gambling to excess.

The National Council of Churches shares these views and also points out that increases in gambling access correspond directly with a diversion of money away from such things as family necessities. In the mid-1990s, the relaxing of a ban on poker machines in Victoria coincided with a major reduction in supermarket takings. Since it is doubtful that the population had drastically reduced its food intake, it is fair to assume that this sudden increase in gambling exposure and availability not only attracted more gamblers but also created more problem gamblers who had presumably escaped the worst excesses previously. Even more concerning is the apparent tendency for those we see hunched over poker machines in pub gambling dens to be from the middle to lower end of the socioeconomic spectrum—the ones who can least afford to give their money away. This is constantly reinforced in my electorate of Parkes. It happens even in the poorest of communities, where the electronic equivalents of the one-armed bandits hold pride of place.

I go into some towns in my electorate where kids roam the streets. Instead of being at school, they roam around and get into trouble and they are hungry, because their parents have succumbed to the vices of drugs, alcohol and gambling—the dreaded pokies. I do not think it is drawing too long a bow to talk about people being genetically pre-disposed to addictive behaviour. I see it everywhere in my electorate: it is the same people with addictive behaviour who are involved in poker machines who also display addictive behaviour in relation to drugs and to alcohol.

The opposition say, `This is too hard; you can't do it. You can't do anything about it, so why are we even trying?' They just throw their hands up in the air and do not even have a go. I believe that there are enough reasons for this government to be in favour of maintaining our numerous social and legislative safeguards on the ease with which people can gamble away their savings. Despite the heavy reliance on gambling revenue, some state governments have shown some willingness to put the brakes on betting outlets such as poker machines. Steps have included longer delays between games, smaller wager limits, along with an awareness campaign and hot lines. I understand there have also been changes made whereby larger winnings must be cashed rather than held over in credits. These steps have been taken because of a radical change in the availability of gambling over the past two or three decades. Yet the move to Internet gambling represents an increase in gambling availability almost overnight that far outstrips the market gains made by the industry in the last 30 years.

This legislation is a concerted attempt by this government to begin to upgrade the safeguards and parameters that have always surrounded gambling to cope with this aggressive and readily presented new strain of gambling. The government has proposed a 12-month moratorium on the development of the local online industry while it weighs the pros and cons of banning or attempting to ban Internet gambling in general. From the days when SP bookies were vigorously pursued by the authorities to the emergence of home delivered instant gambling, often by use of credit cards, this represents a massive increase in the risks inherent in gambling. It even erodes those tiny barriers to blowing more money on betting by eliminating the need to get dressed up to go out to the pub or the club, for example, or the need to at least get up and replace lost funds at a cash machine whereby there is more likelihood of a gambler in some way keeping track of his or her losses.

This government seeks to call to a halt this aggressive expansion so we can fully weigh these issues, but we will make no decision until the results of a study into the feasibility of banning Internet gambling are known. There is no doubt Australian owned gambling sites will reap huge amounts of money from hapless gamblers. If it were not so, the opportunity would not have been pursued by them with anything like the same vigour. Some members opposite talk about exporting jobs overseas. So what? If we want to take that same line of argument, we could talk about the many jobs in the tobacco and alcohol industries—whether in manufacture, distribution or, if we take it a bit further down the line, in the health field with doctors, nurses and physiotherapists. Sure there are jobs associated with this industry, but there are jobs associated with other industries that we have come to learn are perhaps less than desirable. Given the choice, we will probably sacrifice some of the jobs—cardiac surgeons, thoracic surgeons, who are treating people with emphysema related to cigarette smoking. We have to look at more than the surface to see whether these are jobs that do not have flow-on effects, whether these are jobs that we actually want to create in Australia. So we must have breathing space to assess the desirability of Internet gambling before the growth of local companies has provided too much employment and government income to ever face the prospect of being removed. That is what we are trying to do here. If we do nothing now, then that sends the message that we will never do anything to try and address this problem. If we allow the industry to take off to the extent where government revenues and social habits are reliant on Internet gambling, there is no way that any government will attack it. This is the one and only opportunity we will have to address this problem. It is only a moratorium. Now, following opposition from the Labor Party, we now have less than seven months to effect this moratorium.

As a new and emerging national industry with more direct access to advertising and promotion, Australian Internet gambling companies will inevitably raise the profile, appeal and acceptability of online punting through aggressive marketing that is not pursued at this stage by offshore operators. Nobody will start an online gambling business in Australia without the intention of cultivating a customer base. At the moment the ones we hear about operating out of the Caribbean do not promote online gambling in Australia as such. But, if we have Australian companies setting up in Australia, they will be doing it to build a customer base and there will be more people exposed to Internet gambling than there are today. One of the previous speakers mentioned—and I tend to agree with him—that even a small brake on somebody's intention to gamble may be enough to cause them to think, `Well, if I am dealing with a company in the Caribbean, how will I be guaranteed that if I do have a win'—which I would have to say is largely unlikely—`I will be able to collect my winnings?' That is just a small brake that needs to be put into the minds of people who may be considering gambling on the Internet. Of the 1,000 sites currently in operation, many are set up in developing nations such as the Caribbean where government regulations are scant. These sites offer no protection to problem gamblers and winnings obtained from these sites come with no guarantee of the winnings being provided to successful participants. This is the sole basis of the argument of the `do nothing' brigade opposite: `It is too hard; don't even try.' What if we took the same line of thinking on our roads? We have cars that can drive at 120, 150 and 200 kilometres an hour, yet we have speed limits because we recognise that it is not safe for the community to drive at those speeds. The cars are capable of doing it. If you apply the same logic put forward by the opposition to that argument we would not have speed limits. We have a speed limit to try to influence the behaviour of people who are able, if they so choose, to drive fast on our roads, but we try to influence them by saying that they should not. Here we are trying to put some legislation in that says, `Sure, we know. At the moment we cannot stop people from gambling on the Internet but we have to send the message out that we as a government, as a nation, have determined that it is not a desirable thing to do. It is not in the best interests of our people.'

Although no safeguards are completely failsafe, I understand much can be done to dramatically restrict access to these foreign sites and to the way that they operate if, after the moratorium, we decide that a total ban is not possible. Again this gives us breathing space to investigate how we can influence the industry. The fantastically lucrative science of liberating gamblers from their money has evolved with lightning speed from the equivalent of horse-drawn carriages to Formula One racing cars within a matter of a few short decades. Despite its appeal to many people, we recognised long ago that gambling in the days of horse-drawn technology held many dangers and needed a number of constraints upon it to limit damage to the community.
