There are some real issues about who gains control, and I think that is a really important aspect that is not addressed in this bill. It is an aspect that will be a driving force behind further amendments that I know Labor will be keen to address in the future.

It also highlights, I think, some issues about Internet voting. Recently I spoke about Internet voting in this House on a private member's motion. When I did some research for that particular debate I realised that the Internet is going much further than just basic e-commerce or basic business to business or business to consumer and further than just information. There is much more out there. We in this place know that because of the use we make of it in our work here. I do not think anybody here could say they could live without email, for example—it is too important to the work we do every day. But Internet voting is, I think, another issue. Another issue is people's rights in relation to the Internet—not just the rights around what names people purchase but their rights in relation to how they are identified and their rights on the Internet.

In the few minutes I have got left I want to mention some of the things that are happening in my electorate of Oxley and how the Internet, technology and new industries are taking a huge leap forward. I have to say I am pretty proud of Ipswich city as a city of innovation. It is a city that is moving ahead, a city that takes the lead. It is a leader in a whole range of areas but particularly in information technology and Internet use. Ipswich city council was the leader in another area: it developed a system called Global Information Links. Through a tech library they set up their own ISP and they have their own local intranet, their own local network. It started off on a city basis and has now gone national. Now they are looking at international business as well. It highlights the importance of this industry and how it can put you on the map.

One of the great businesses I have in my electorate is a business called Claypave. Those from Queensland should know who Claypave are. They have won a number of Queensland business awards—Queensland Business of the Year, and a range of things. They make pavers, obviously, and bricks. You would not think that a paver manufacturer, a brick manufacturer, would be into high technology or that they would have a web page or that they would win an award and do a range of business through the Internet, but they do. They have established a web site. You can go on to their web site, pick the paver you want, order it through the web and have it delivered to your home. That sounds a bit simple, but they go further than that. They say, `We can match the colour brick you want on your screen.' They have a colour matching system; you go out the back, pick up a paver you want to match, bring it inside, take it to your screen and basically hold it up and match it up with one of their pavers. They have used this technology to do business not only here in Australia but also internationally by being able to link up with companies overseas that are looking for particular tenders and orders. They say, `Here is a company we can deal with online and get the product almost online. We can look at the colours.' They rate it; they do a range of things.

One of the important things with any discussion about technology is the importance you place on it. The Internet super highway relates to a number of issues in my electorate. When we talk about super highways, you cannot go past how important highways and roads are. I remember reading some time ago that the most important invention of the 20th century was the road. The simple road was the most important invention. It is an important invention because it links people together—it links communities together and it networks people. That is what the Internet does; that is what the web does. In relation to roads, while I was very pleased that the government put together a Roads to Recovery package involving $1.2 billion, and though it was very welcome, I have to say that there was a range of criticisms about that. One of the criticisms I have relates to a National Party Roads to Recovery package release. Helen Dickey from the National Party says in this release:

quote.para: This package is the most significant achievement of the National Party in modern times.

speech.para: When I read that, my mind straight away went to the time I read about the road being the most important invention of the 20th century. If this is the most important thing that the National Party have done in modern times, that is pretty significant. I thought: how did they come to this? To have a package that is so significant in modern times, they must have been working on it for 80 years. Fifty years? Twenty years? Ten years? So I thought I would have a look at it and see how this package came about. I discovered that this package was not something that the National Party and the coalition had been working on for years and years. It looked to me more like a knee-jerk reaction to a lot of bad press about fuel prices. It looked to me as though a few people were sitting around the cabinet room and they were saying, `How are we going to get over this really bad do-do sandwich that we have to eat?' So they said, `Let's come up with absolutely the best package that we could ever come up with in modern times.' So the National Party have said, `Why don't we put together this Roads to Recovery package?'

So we all appreciate this package very much. Oxley was treated quite well in the package. In the official documents it said $40 million. I have to say that I was pretty happy when I saw it—$40 million. I thought: this is fantastic. I thought I would go and have a look at it myself to see exactly what that $40 million would get me. In the electorate of Oxley we obviously have Ipswich, which is going to get about $5,336,844 over four years. Hear, Hear! The problem I have in Oxley is that I have only half of Ipswich. The member for Blair has the other half of Ipswich. And therein lies my problem because I fear that perhaps I will not get all of that $5 million in the electorate of Oxley. But, hopefully, I will get my fair half. So there goes at least $2.5 million of my $40 million—gone out the door before we even start.

So I thought I would have a closer look. My electorate also has part of the City of Brisbane, so I thought, `How much is Brisbane getting in this package?' They are getting about $28 million—I thought I would be very appreciative, but I thought, `Hang on, how many federal electorates are sharing Brisbane's money?' Eleven federal electorates. What do I get? What is Oxley's share? I am told I am going to get $40 million; but what is my share? What is Oxley really going to get? If you divide $28 million by 11 you ain't got much left. Let's say I get $2.5 million.

talk.start.para: —The member for Oxley might care to tie his remarks to the telecommunications amendment bill to facilitate the debate.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker, I will. The importance of telecommunications, and particularly in the bill here, is that it is about networks, about linking people together and those structures that bring people together. There is nothing more important than the networks of roads that link all Australians and all communities. If you want to talk about rural and regional roads or rural and regional networks, whether it is contained in the telecommunications bill or whether it is contained in a Roads to Recovery package, we are talking about the same principles and the same thing. We are talking about a commitment to those communities, to the bush and to regional areas. It is quite important and quite relevant that we look at these packages and say, `How much are we really getting? What are we getting for our dollar?' I have been led to believe, because I have it in writing in a wonderful letter from the government, that I am going to get over $40 million. And I have to say that I am pretty thankful.

speech.para: But when I started looking at it even closer, I thought, `Hang on, there's more money here. But wait, there's more.' I have a part of Boonah shire, and they are getting about $970,000. But how much do you think Oxley will get of that? Pretty close to nothing. We will get nothing. So from $40 million, I am still only on about $4 million to $5 million at best; that is tops. But it does not end there; there is always a little bit more. I also have Logan. I have one suburb in Logan, and I appreciate Logan very much. Forestdale in Logan is a fantastic area. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Neville) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 6 February 2001, at 2 p.m., unless the Speaker or, in the event of the Speaker being unavailable, the Deputy Speaker, fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting.

speech.para: That is the formal way of introducing what is known in the trade as the valedictories or, less reverently on occasions, the `hypocrisies'. We have reached that occasion at the end of the year when we say a few words of goodwill, and I hope in a very gracious and decent way towards each other. When you come to the end of the year, you look back and I do not think there is any doubt that the year 2000 has been a wonderful year for Australia. It is a year, undoubtedly, that was dominated by the huge success of the Olympic Games and the Paralympics, which did great things for our country. Whatever our political views may be, our successes have been a source of tremendous pride to me as Prime Minister of this country.
Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I see the Chief Opposition Whip and, to borrow the words of Prince Hal from King Henry IV, `I do see a good amendment of life in thee.' Anything is an improvement.

speech.para: It has been, by any measure, a wonderful year for our country. When all of the political rhetoric is put aside, we are meant to be here first and foremost to advance and, where appropriate, acclaim the interests of our country. The last year has been a very good year for Australia. It is a year that saw us put on a wonderful display to the rest of the world and a year that demonstrated all of the openness, decency and egalitarian spirit of our country and our capacity to do things in an efficient, modern and sophisticated way. All of those associated with that wonderful event deserve our credit. It has also been a very momentous year politically. It is a year that at a national level has undoubtedly been dominated by the debate about a new taxation system. I do not seek to talk about the partisan aspects, merely to record as a matter of fact and reality that the debate about that issue has dominated more of the airwaves on federal politics and more hectares of newsprint on federal politics than any other event.

It has also been a year, as I noted this morning, as did the Leader of the Opposition and others, that has seen the cause of reconciliation significantly advanced. Whatever may be people's views about whether we have a treaty or an agreement or the forms of expression we might use in relation to past events in the history of this country, nobody can argue about the tremendous support in our community for reconciliation. The cause of reconciliation has been very greatly enhanced and advanced over the last 12 months, and I know that is a source of satisfaction to people on both sides of the House. I certainly find, as I go around the Australian community, a great desire to emphasise the things that we agree on in relation to the cause of reconciliation.

It has also been a year that has seen levels of unemployment reach a 10-year low. It has been a year which has seen the living standards of the Australian people greatly enhanced, but it has also been a year in which we are reminded that there are still many in our community who are deprived, poor and underprivileged. As we come to Christmas, we are reminded of the obligation we have as a government and also the obligation we have as human beings to assist those in our community who are less well cared for.

Quite apart from the Olympic Games, it has also been a year of quite stunning sporting achievements for Australia. I do not think there would be any man or woman in this parliament who would deny the importance of sport in the national psyche, and there seems to be an almost endless parade of Australian sporting achievements. I was reminded of this the weekend before last when I watched a Sky News broadcast. They had the Australian bit, then the English bit and then the sporting bit of the English bit, and that is always quite good. At the end of it, almost with a sort of dismayed, downtrodden lament, the commentator said, `And Australia has added yet another World Cup to her winning retinue by winning the Rugby League World Cup at Old Trafford.' I am delighted to say that in honour of that great victory, along with people from both sides of the parliament, there will be a gathering held at Kirribilli House in Sydney the week after next to salute the achievement of the Australian rugby league team, which has for 25 years in a row won the World Cup. It is a metaphor for the great sporting success of our country and, given my own prejudices in this area, I cannot leave sport without saying something about the 12 in a row.

talk.start.para: —And the Adelaide Crows.

—No, the 12 in a row and the magnificent achievement of Steve Waugh's Australian cricket team, which has established a world record. I cannot think of anything more appropriate to crown a great Australian sporting year than to salute the fact that the Australian cricket team has established a world record in winning 12 test matches in a row.

speech.para: Coming closer to home in terms of the federal parliament, Christmas is an occasion for me as Prime Minister—and this is the fifth occasion that I as Prime Minister of this country have had the privilege—to offer some valedictories. First of all, in the spirit of Christian charity towards those who sit opposite, I wish Mr Kim Beazley and his family—Susie, his wife, and his children—a very merry Christmas. I hope Kim and Susie have a very relaxing Christmas. I mean that very genuinely. There is no point in spending years of your life in this place and carrying unnecessary malice towards those who sit opposite. I believe in fierce political competition, but I also believe in recognising that, in all of us, there is an innate sense of decency and a desire to do good things for the country. I disagree very strongly with my political opponents about how that is best done, but I do not carry any innate malice or ill will towards them. I offer to my opposite number the very best of Christmas good wishes, and I hope that he has a relaxing time and spends plenty of time with his family and does whatever he wishes to do at Christmas. I suspect that in one or two sporting areas he will be interested in things not terribly dissimilar from what I might wish to do. I hope he comes back refreshed and invigorated and is ready for all that we might hurl at him. I wish him well and I wish all those who sit opposite a very happy Christmas.

I think Christmas is a time for family consolidation. It is a time for spiritual and personal reflection. I do not seek to impose any particular stereotype of Christmas on people. Mine is a fairly orthodox and predictable one, and I guess it is one shared by many who sit opposite but, equally, for those who do not hold that view of Christmas, I respect their view also. I acknowledge that it is also a time—whatever people's views are—to spend with family and friends and to reflect upon the great good fortune of being a healthy Australian and living in an atmosphere of relative affluence and relative good fortune.

I have occasion at the end of this year to thank a lot of people on my own side. I am a very lucky man, indeed. I have a wonderful family. I have a very supportive wife and three magnificent children. They have made whatever success I have achieved in politics entirely possible; without them I would not have achieved that. I thank them very warmly, and I record my gratitude to Janette, Melanie, Tim and Richard. They mean more to me than anything else in the world.

I also want to thank my colleagues on the government frontbench. John Anderson is a wonderful Deputy Prime Minister. He is a very decent and effective Leader of the National Party, a great minister and a person who exhibits very great personal qualities. I thank you very warmly, John, for the loyalty and support that you have given me throughout the year. It is a great partnership. The greatest political partnership Australia has ever seen is the partnership between the Liberal Party and the National Party. It is the partnership that sustains our government. It helps fill the pews of the broad church, extending the ecclesiastical metaphor that I frequently use about the government. I think, John, you do an absolutely wonderful job.
To Peter Costello, who—

talk.start.para: —He is not far away.

—He is never far away! I want to thank Peter. This has been a great year for the Treasurer because he has presided over the detailed implementation of the greatest overhaul ever of the Australian taxation system. I want to very warmly record my thanks to and admiration for Peter Costello for all the work that he has done. To my other leadership colleagues—Robert Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate; Richard Alston, the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate; and Mark Vaile, the Deputy Leader of the National Party—I extend my very warm thanks, as I do to all of my cabinet colleagues and to all of my parliamentary colleagues. Being an effective government is very much a team effort. I may be the public face of the government but, without the loyalty and support that I have received from the men and women who sit behind me, I would not have been able to be an effective public face, and of course there are some in the community—I have heard of them—who do not think I am an effective public face. But to all of you, who have given much such loyalty and help, thank you. You are a great crowd of men and women, and it is tremendous to have you working with me.

speech.para: Also, I especially extend my thanks to my personal staff. The staff of a prime minister in a prime minister's office is a very closely-knit circle. I express my very great gratitude to Arthur Sinodinos, my chief of staff, who is well known to all of those who sit behind; to Tony Nutt, my principal private secretary, who knows more about the labyrinthine workings of the Liberal Party organisation around Australia than most—and it is very important for a prime minister to know about that—and to all of the members of my staff. Also, I have appreciated the assistance on a very regular basis of those who run that Liberal Party organisation. We are all creatures in one way or another of a party organisation. I want to record my gratitude to Shane Stone, the National President of the Liberal Party of Australia, and Lynton Crosby, the Federal Director—both are very close friends of mine and both contribute on a political side to the effective working of the government. That is indeed very important, and I extend that thanks to the presidents of the various state divisions of the Liberal Party.

Sir, I extend to you a very merry Christmas and to Ian Harris and Bernard Wright, the clerks, who are unfailing polite, efficient, intelligent and, on all occasions, eminently fair in the advice that they give to both sides of the parliament. I thank them very warmly.

I also thank those two people who make the House, on an hourly basis, so effective. I refer, first of all, to my colleague the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and the Leader of the House. I think it is fair to say that he has had a lively year—but he adds a lively year this year to years of great achievement. He has been a great Leader of the House and a great reforming minister. Of all the statistics that were posted during this year, there were none of which I was more proud than that 25-an-hour crane rate that was posted the other day. It was a great achievement and I warmly thank him. I also thank the Manager of Opposition Business in the House of Representatives for his unfailing contribution to the colour of question time, if I can put it that way. I was once a Manager of Opposition Business. I do not know whether I resigned from that or was tipped out of it, but I once held the position and it is an important part of the way in which the parliament operates.

I want to thank all the staff of the parliament, including the liaison officer from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, which helps make everything run so very effectively. I thank the Hansard people. I am filled with admiration, after 26 years in this place, at the skill and dexterity of people who run Hansard. I also thank the broadcasting and technical services staff, the staff of the Joint House Department, those who arrange our transport, all of the people who keep us safe and secure, those in Jetset Travel and in the Table Office, the assistant parliamentary liaison officer and everybody else who has played a very important role in making the parliament work. There is another group of people who I think are also very important, and that is the whips. I think is fair to say—
Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I understand they are all good-natured interjections, but I think the Prime Minister should at least be able to be heard.

—I think Ronno has had a good year. I want to thank the member for Corangamite and the member for Forde, who have provided tremendous assistance. I also want to thank—and I know my colleague the Deputy Prime Minister will have something to say of this—the member for Mallee and the member for Hinkler, the whip and assistant of the National Party, and also my colleagues who are the government whips in the Senate.
—Who?
—His name is Forrest and he is the member for Mallee, isn't he?
—Yes.

—That's right; that's what I thought. I know they are terrific, and they have all made an impact on you. And they keep telling me they are the people I ought to thank. All of these people have made a very important role in making it an absolutely wonderful year for the national parliament.

speech.para: There are just two other relatively serious things that I want to say. The first of those is to ask all members of parliament to remember, as we celebrate Christmas, that there will be men and women serving this country abroad, who by reason of that service will be separated from their families. They are the men and women of the Australian Defence Force who are serving in East Timor, Bougainville and the Solomon Islands, and of the Australian Federal Police elsewhere around the world. It is incumbent on all of us to remember them and to record our special respect.

The other thing that I would like to say is that, as we come to the end of another parliamentary year, it is important to remember that we are all extremely privileged people. In this House we are but 148 Australians who are chosen every three years to represent 19 million people, to sit in the national parliament. We are privileged to belong to a democracy. We have a strong and robust parliamentary system. We have a free press and we have an incorruptible judiciary. Those three things, more than anything else, keep this country together and guarantee its freedom. The greatest honour that I have had in my public life is to be a representative of the 75,000 or 80,000 people who vote in my electorate every year. To be a representative of the Australian people in this parliament is a great honour, and it is something that I always treasure very deeply and regard very warmly.

I conclude my remarks by wishing all members of the House a very merry Christmas. I hope they have happy times with their families and friends and that they come back refreshed when we rejoin the inevitable battle which is the stuff and the substance of Australia's parliamentary democracy.

talk.start.para: —It is a very great pleasure for me to participate yet again in these valedictories. I have been doing this for a long time now: almost five years as Leader of the Opposition and for about—
—There'll be many more.

—One more, but not next Christmas. Before then, I spent something like seven or eight years as Leader of the House, so these processes are very familiar to me. I thank the Prime Minister for the good wishes that he extended to me, my family and my colleagues, and I would like very much to reciprocate those good wishes to him and his family. I know how much his wife and his children mean to him. They are a source of enormous strength to him, as indeed are my family to me.

speech.para: That is the case for most of us in political life. Ours is a burdensome profession for families. Some of us do it very successfully, some of us experience great tragedy in our family life, and all of us are tremendously dependent on the non-parliamentary spouse in the partnership for the success or otherwise of our family life. It is an enormously significant ballast to us in public life. Of course, at Christmas time we think in the first instance about our own families and then extend our gratitude, joy and best wishes to the families of the nation. I particularly thank my family tonight, as the Prime Minister has thanked his. I know how much I depend on Susie and how much my daughters mean to me. I owe them an enormous debt of gratitude.

I mention in passing that one parliamentary family had a father last Christmas and this year does not. My thoughts go out to Greg Wilton's widow, his two children, his mother and his sister. They have our best wishes and thoughts at this very difficult time. When tragedy of any description strikes, you feel your loneliness most at the great public celebrations and commemorations such as Christmas. Our thoughts and prayers are with them.

It is an extraordinary thing—I suppose if I were a more expert observer of our weather, I would have a better comprehension of it—that always at this time of year we reflect upon the fact that in some part of Australia somebody's Christmas is ruined, usually on a very large scale. We think very much tonight in these valedictories of those who have suffered flood damage, particularly those around the electorate of the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party and further afield. It will not be much of a Christmas for many hundreds of people this year, but at least they have each other—and there is much comfort in that. This terrible season was not accompanied by any large loss of life, and for that we ought to be enormously grateful.

Of course I join the Prime Minister in wishing all the best to, and extending our understanding to, those who are serving our country overseas. They do us all a great honour in being prepared to lay their lives on the line for the nation and for all of us. That service brings with it many discomforts, as well as, I suspect, a very deep sense of personal satisfaction. One of those discomforts is the absence of family life at this joyous time of the year. So, as the Prime Minister said, our thoughts go out to our serving personnel in Timor and elsewhere around the world.

It has been a fabulous year in many ways for the Australian people, in the life of the nation and our society. There is no doubt at all that we are beginning to get blasé about sporting achievements in this nation. The 12 tests in a row, the World Cups, the Olympics: any one of these events and triumphs would have occupied us in discussion around the kitchen table for weeks and weeks, but to have them occur serially throughout the year is almost a surfeit—not that we wish it to go away—of success. In the Australian heart and mind, that is a source of enormous joy.

I look back on the Olympics and Paralympics in particular, not just for the sporting spectacle but for what it said about us as a people. There was the sporting triumph. It is arguably the case—and I am not sure whether this will ever be repeated—that there is no international sporting meet at which Australia was more successful across a multiplicity of sports gathered for a competition in one broadly based event than our Paralympic team. Our Olympic team was the most successful ever but, arguably, I do not think anyone has dominated a sporting event in the way that the Australians dominated the Paralympics, short of the Americans at the Moscow-absent sports in the US or the Russians at the American-absent sports at the Moscow Olympics.

talk.start.para: —And they did it honestly.

—Absolutely. As one of my number, the member for Cowan—who was very prominent in events at the time—says, there was a straightness in the way in which our athletes were classified that adds to the triumph. A question mark has subsequently been placed over athletes from other nations.

speech.para: The Prime Minister mentioned reconciliation. One of the things I loved was the evidence that that spirit of reconciliation and generosity of heart had spread so deep in the Australian community that it could be seen at events associated with the Olympics and the Paralympics. I suppose one would expect the huge audience to have a certain amount of physical resources to get to the Olympics. As I can say painfully from personal experience, it was not cheap. But there was a marvellous spirit.

The Paralympics were attended by huge numbers of westies. It was a marvellous leavening of ordinary, average Aussies, and that same spirit prevailed. It was a wonderful demonstration of the fact that opinions, attitudes and views of life in this community have turned decisively. It makes me look forward to next year's Centenary of Federation celebrations enormously. I think we can now look objectively at our history and look with great hope to our future. I believe we will have a real opportunity to do that next year.

Personally, I went on a pilgrimage—which the Prime Minister also went on and extended—to Gallipoli earlier in the year. I will always present the arguable view—I know others will dispute it—that we developed a sense of ourselves as a coherent nation, with a national posture and identity, during World War I, and the identifying focal point of that particular conflict is always Gallipoli. As you go, as I did as a Western Australian—and it was Western Australians who first landed—and look at the names on the graves, they are exactly the same names as the people I went to primary school with: the Hancocks, the Chippers—the Chipperfields—all the people I went to school with. They are the names of those from the 10th Light Horse and the Western Australian Infantry Battalion that made that landing. I was appreciative of the fact that I was able to go on that particular pilgrimage, and for me that was set up as a highlight of the year.

We have much to be grateful for, and those of us who are leaders in this place have more to be grateful for than most. I would like to extend my thanks in the first instance to the members of my caucus. I have a wonderful caucus, a supportive caucus, an intelligent caucus, a youthful caucus—so youthful it is reproducing itself at an extraordinarily rapid rate. We have had one bub this year. That follows bubs last year and there are three more on the way in the course of the next few months. It is a habit not unknown, I know, on the other side of the House. When I was an academic teaching at Murdoch University the entirety of the women on the floor I was on were pregnant at the same time, and I remember a colleague walking down the corridor saying, `There's a depressing air of fecundity in this corridor.' Well, there is an elevating air of fecundity on the opposition benches, and a number of my colleagues are going to have a totally joyous Christmas or immediate aftermath of Christmas, I believe, and we will all be enjoying it along with them; it is a terrific thing.

My caucus is a supportive, intelligent, hardworking caucus, and my front bench reflects it. I am particularly grateful to my colleagues for the work they have done, particularly at our national conference this year but also in the evolution of development of policy: they are a constant source of support and hard work. I would not want to isolate any particular individuals, but two I must. The first of those is my deputy, Simon Crean, who is a magnificently pugnacious fighter in this chamber. I happen to believe that a trade union background is an excellent training ground for the life of politics and an appreciation of what happens among the ordinary, the average, households of this nation. I get plenty of good advice and plenty of good support from that background. So Simon I would very much want to thank. Then I would also want to thank Bob McMullan, who manages our affairs in this place. He does it so well and so effectively, and he is of course a constant source of support. They are from my front bench.

The Prime Minister said how grateful he was for the powerhouse he felt in Australian politics that emanated from the coalition of the Liberal and National parties. I take joy in the fact that we do it on our own. I take joy in the fact that we are capable of sustaining government in this place out of our one political party. And I take joy in the fact that we have been doing it for 100 years. One of the celebrations I look forward to next year is the celebration that will take place one day before we have the celebration of the centenary of our Commonwealth parliament, and that will be the centenary of the federal Labor caucus—older than this parliament. As you can see, I have much to be grateful for.

Our federal parliamentary Labor Party is held together, coherent as an effective fighting force in the life of the nation, by in the first instance our whips. Therefore I want to extend my particular thanks to the Chief Whip, Leo McLeay, and to the Whips Rod Sawford and Bob Sercombe—and of course to the office which backs them up so effectively of Joan Connor and Ann Stewart. Our whips are quiet, gentle, fair-minded, unconfrontational, understanding, liberating and fair. Without them we simply could not survive. I would also, of course, extend my thanks to the wider party organisation in its state branches but also at our national level. We have a new National Secretary in Geoff Walsh, and he is proving to be a most effective one. I am very glad to have him on board. I believe that he does for us a very good job of work indeed.

Here in parliament all of us on both sides of the House are well served by our clerks, Ian Harris and Bernard Wright, and their colleagues in the Clerks Office. They are impartial to a fault, almost. They are properly protective of the Speaker, and they give him very sound advice. They are the people who really keep our organisation here legal, and that is a very important point—something that a lot of us do not really appreciate: how legislation is carried and passed between the houses is fundamental to the legality of the things that we do in this place. We often think of Ian and Bernard as standing orders experts, here merely to keep us appropriately apart. We do not actually need to be kept apart: we have a table here. It is more important in the House of Commons, which is structured to keep two sword-lengths from the two front benches. We are more distant than two sword-lengths, and we tend to think of the clerks in that context. But the clerks actually play a role in keeping us legal in this place. It is a job demanding enormous expertise.

I would also like to thank the new Parliamentary Liaison Officer, Alistair Sherwin, and Pam and Helen, who work so hard there. I thank the folk in the Bills and Papers Office and the Tables Office; the research staff; the Sergeant-at-Arms, Judy Middlebrook, and Dalma Dixon and their very helpful staff; and the Hansard staff, who have perhaps the toughest job in this place, turning our perorations into English—and especially to Bret Gaynor, who is leaving soon I understand to go to Perth. I am sorry that Bret is leaving, but I cannot criticise his determination to locate himself in God's own part of Australia.

The other House of Representatives staff members, including the printing staff and their attendants: I do wish them well for Christmas and the New Year. We in opposition, in particular, would make a special mention of the Parliamentary Library staff, who are such a vital resource for all members of parliament but a particularly important source of support for an opposition.

I thank too all the Joint House staff, including the cleaning staff, the maintenance staff, the gardeners, the marketing and visitors staff, and the security people; the switchboard, and health and recreation staff. I thank too the cafeteria and Aussies cafe, the shop operators, the bank staff, the post office workers, the Qantas staff, hairdressers, florists and Comcar drivers. I make particular mention here of a gentleman who has driven me for a very long time, Alan McKenzie, who has just retired; and Rick Boyland, who still drives me in Perth.

But, when we are mentioning staff, I guess for those of us who hold the sort of office I hold there is one group of staff who are most enormously significant to it, and that is our own personal staff—those in the office here in Canberra and those in my office in Perth. I have a substantial and large staff, but I must make particular mention here of my chief of staff, Mike Costello, who has been a marvellous addition to our ranks. And I give a special reference to Karen Bissaker, who has just had her second child. We miss her very much but welcome the birth of baby Sophie. But, as I have said, our staff are a source of constant support to us, as members of parliament, those of us in leadership positions. We in the opposition are enormously dependent on those staff that we are permitted under the arrangements, and I thank them and wish them all the best for Christmas and the New Year.

We also should extend—and I do extend—on behalf of the opposition best wishes to all Australians at this time, particularly those doing it tough: the elderly, the homeless, the mentally ill and the sole parents. I wish them all the joy that they can get from this season. It is a joyous season basically for all of us. I wish every one of us here a safe and happy Christmas and New Year. I have enjoyed this year enormously; I think next year is going to be even more enjoyable. As we develop our character as a nation—as we develop self-confidence in our institutions and in our attitudes, our tolerance, our decency and our understanding of what a great thing it is to be an Australian—our national events seem to take on even more character. I think that next year's national events associated with the Centenary of Federation will be a further demonstration, a further opportunity to do that.

I have been passed a note, but I did not need to be. I was leaving my last valedictory to the Speaker. You preside, Mr Speaker; you have a very tough job. I remember Harry Jenkins, who held your position, had one way of remonstrating with recalcitrant members of parliament which I have never heard any other Speaker use before or since. He always used to say, `You're not assisting the chair.' I do not think it is our job really to assist the chair. It is, however, our job to pay it respect—and, Mr Speaker, we do do that to you. To you and your family, Mr Speaker, I hope you have a most enjoyable and satisfying Christmas. I look forward to even more new and interesting rulings from you during what is going to be a savage year next year.
Honourable members—Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: —The year 2000 I think in many ways has been a quite remarkable year. Many of the things that have happened during the year have been referred to by the previous two speakers. It began in a most remarkable blaze of fireworks here and in cities right across Australia. Indeed, as I came down the next morning to check out what had happened with Y2K, we were able to watch midmorning on that 1 January here in Canberra, care of modern technology, the fireworks in London and right around the world, as we marked the beginning of a new age. Later in the year we held our breath as the Olympic cauldron wobbled and then ascended into the sky. We cheered as our own Australians ran for gold. We have watched as people have performed to the best of their ability and reflected, I think, very great credit on this nation—not only in the things that have been won but I think too in the graciousness with which Australians have participated in cheering on those who have not only won but given of their best, and often extended that graciousness to those who were not even competing for Australia. I think one of the most endearing memories of the Olympics, for me at least, was to see that sort of wonderful spirit of cheering on the underdogs who from time to time were not even from our own country but were giving it their best shot.

speech.para: I should say at the outset of my remarks that there was tragedy as well. In my own electorate, many people are still cleaning up after the worst wet period in living memory—I will not say floods, because they were only a minor part of the problem. It was the timing and extended period of rain that did the damage in north-western New South Wales and beyond. Many, as the Leader of the Opposition commented, will not particularly enjoy their Christmas this year as a result. Many will be years recovering financially. Can I take this opportunity—although I will say a little more in a moment about the Prime Minister—to say that I am particularly thankful that he was able to come and see first-hand what had happened, to meet with the affected people. I extend my thanks also to the Treasurer, who visited the electorate over that time and, indeed, the Leader of the Opposition who visited Walgett, faced with the unusual problem that people sit there for several days waiting, as the water slowly comes towards them and slowly rises—you can be standing out on a nice sunny day in a dry paddock, watching the water creep towards you. It is a quite extraordinary situation for them.

But while all of this has happened, the rhythm of our work as parliamentarians has continued. I certainly join with the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition in acknowledging the work of the staff in this place. Their work is essential. They keep to a very great degree the same punishing hours as we do, but they receive no recognition—they are seen only in the background very often, as we speak and act out our roles on the public stage.

I think too those remarks that go to the issue of reconciliation have been appropriate. We have all, I think, grown in our understanding of these issues. We do not always have a monochrome view of how best to progress the difficult matters that confront us as we seek to build harmony and greater respect in the way that we live alongside one another, but we all acknowledge the great importance of progressing that agenda in a spirit of respect for one another's shared humanity

I know for my own part that I will never be quite the same having witnessed, near the small town of Delungra earlier this year, the unveiling of the memorial to the massacre that took place at Myall Creek in 1838—just three years before my own family moved into that immediate area. To see a direct descendant of one of the men who was hanged for murder, who had herself discovered only a couple of months before that she was a descendant of one of those who had been hanged, embracing a direct descendant of one of the people who had been murdered was a very profoundly moving experience. I think it left all who saw it touched at a very deep level. We all go through our journey in life, and I must say that was quite a profound moment for me and, I think, for others who saw it—not just perhaps those who were present but also those who saw it on national television.

Mr Speaker, I certainly record my thanks to you for your role in this place. I also thank the Clerk, Ian Harris, and Bernard, and all your people, for your professionalism and decency and for the quiet and understated way in which you deliver that professionalism and decency. I also thank the parliamentary reporters and the library. I would particularly like to salute the parliamentary retrieval service staff, who have a quite magical ability to retrieve obscure books from the National Library in record time. I thank the staff of the Joint House Department who do such a superb job of running Parliament House and maintaining the gardens. Sometimes I look enviously at the resources that go into them and think we could help build a Scoresby or a local road or whatever—some amazing resources go into them—but I in no way take away from those who look after them, deliver them and build them up. I must say the gardens are now, to my way of thinking, achieving some patina of maturity. They really are very attractive and a great credit to those who look after them so well. Some of us were out in one of those gardens over on the Senate side at lunchtime today at Boz's annual seafood barbecue and it really was a truly beautiful place to be.

Jetset Travel do a very competent job. The Australian Protective Service describe themselves as `a bunch of regular blokes', but we describe them—I think the Prime Minister would agree—as very fine human beings. I also thank the Comcar staff and the people of 34 Squadron, including one of their newest young recruits, Malcolm Walker, who was a neighbour of mine back at Mullaley—although his family have now moved away. He now finds himself in the Air Force and, at least at this stage, with 34 Squadron. In my own case can I mention, as one who relies heavily on charter—and I think members will understand that, given my particular role as leader of a party that has major interests in rural and regional Australia—Don McAllister and Andrew Major. I rely heavily on them in between times.

I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his good wishes tonight, and extend mine to him and to Susie as well. I join the Prime Minister in saying that I hope that you and your team enjoy a restful and relaxing Christmas period.

I thank the Prime Minister for his kind remarks. Can I say that I too believe it is a very effective coalition that has delivered, and continues to deliver, a stronger Australia with firmer economic and social foundations. I enjoy very much being part of that team, I really do. I think it is fair to say that something we are both privileged to enjoy and appreciate very much are supportive families. I could not do this without Julia. She is to me the most wonderful person I have ever met. Our four children, younger than the Prime Minister's—
Government members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You understand that I am a little biased in this instance. My kids are younger than the Prime Minister's, but I suppose the Prime Minister's grew up having really known little other than the political life—
—The problem is I am older than you.

—I am going grey rapidly. But I do thank Jessica, Nicholas, Georgina and Laura for being, particularly in the context of their ages, very understanding and supportive of what Dad tries to do. Can I say to the Prime Minister and Janette: have a good break. We will look after the shop—do not worry about it. I recall well, during the first Christmas break you took when Tim Fischer was relieving, that there was a marvellous Moir cartoon one day. Tim had a couple of issues running at the time and Moir had a cartoon.

—I can tell that Peter Reith remembers it. It showed a china shop, there were several bulls rampaging around the china shop smashing a few things up and the names of the various issues that Tim had running were written on the sides of the bulls. A telephone call came through from Hawks Nest and Tim was hanging onto the chandelier with one hand and holding a telephone in the other saying, `No, John, everything is absolutely fine. Go back to the beach and just relax.' I remember that well.
—There was the directly elected president.

—That was one of the bulls running around the china shop. I thank Peter Costello and Tanya for the very important role they have performed on behalf of the government and indeed the nation. It has been a long and hard year for the Treasurer—it really has. He has to deliver against all sorts of difficulties, not least of which are caused by those of us who occasionally feel the urge to spend money. I think he has done a very great job of oversighting major reform and at the same time maintaining financial discipline and economic management as a critical part of the government team.

speech.para: I thank my deputy leader, Mark Vaile, and his wife, Wendy. Like the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mark faces the added difficulties of travelling not just between his electorate, Parliament House and other regions of Australia but internationally as well. I take my hat off to both gentlemen for the work that they do. I particularly thank Mark and wish him a good break over Christmas.

I thank the whips. I thank Ronno. He is still here watching. Certainly I thank the Mallee bull, John Forrest; the member for Hinkler, Paul Neville, with his magnificent sense of humour and his great ability to pick us all up when we are feeling a little bit flat; and my other colleagues in the parliamentary National Party, including Ron Boswell. Thank you very much indeed for your commitment and your hard work this year.

I thank my personal staff, particularly my principal adviser, Stephen Oxley, who leads a very fine team. I thank my electorate staff, who battle on and have battled on through a very difficult time with the floods. I think they have done a very good job. I would particularly like to mention Julia Dimitriadis, my longstanding aviation departmental liaison officer. She has been up here for three years and has done an absolutely superb and very professional job. She returns to the Department of Transport and Regional Services after three years in this place, and my office will miss her very much indeed. I would also like to mention Gaye White, the federal director of the National Party, the state organisations and the people who staff all of those.

On a personal note, I thank all of those—many in this place—who were kind enough to contact me when I was a bit crook a couple of months ago. I have to say that it was worth the effort. I got to the bottom of a little underlying problem that I had not known about, and I have never felt better. The words of encouragement and support helped me get through that slightly painful time. I do thank the medicos as well, particularly the medico in Sydney who said to me, `Sign this. You've only got a two per cent chance of losing your voice for life, but I think it will be worth it.' I was luckily not amongst the two per cent.

It is easy to forget in the bustle of our lives that there is more to this world than parliamentary sittings, meetings and plane trips. Christmas is a time for us to relax, unwind and enjoy time with our families. Certainly for me and my wife, it is a time to reflect upon that very significant birth a couple of thousand years ago and to know that that miracle still has consequences for us all. I say to you, Mr Speaker, that I wish you and all honourable members the very best for Christmas and a prosperous, happy and fruitful 2001 as we celebrate our centenary year.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, may I interrupt before the Manager of Opposition Business speaks. The latest on the deliberations of the Senate is that the Senate are currently considering the renewable energy legislation. They are expecting to return to the Gene Technology Bill 2000 at 11.30 or quarter to 12, and they have just short of 40 amendments still to deal with. The whip, the Manager of Opposition Business and I—and anybody else who is particularly interested—intend to review the situation at around 12.30. Then we might have to make a decision as to whether we think the Senate are actually going to conclude matters tonight. It is still my view that, provided it is not totally unreasonable, we should try to finish, whatever hour it is, because most people have said that they would like to get away, but we will review it at about 12.30 when we have a better idea of what is happening, and we will keep you informed. Thank you for allowing me to interrupt.

speech.para: Consideration resumes.

talk.start.para: —It is my pleasure to join in the remarks made by the various leaders. It is not appropriate for those of us who speak in these debates who are not leaders to range so widely as those three who have spoken before me, so I will more directly relate my comments to those people who we on the opposition side and I as Manager of Opposition Business most particularly wish to thank.

speech.para: I would like to break that rule slightly to say that, while I endorse and welcome the remarks that the three leaders have made about the wonderful sporting achievements this year—those who know me know that I can be as enthusiastic a sports junkie as any of those here—I want to try to broaden the perception of the great achievements of this nation by referring to the great artistic achievements of Australians throughout the year, those who participate in and contribute to the cultural life of our country. To take an example, the Olympics would not have been the same without the fantastic cultural contribution of many, including those from the Bangarra Dance Theatre who contributed to the opening ceremony and put on their haunting and demanding program, Skin, throughout the Olympic artistic festival. I think we need to make sure we do not become too narrow in our enthusiasms.

As a former senator, I also want to comment on the rather depressing comments just made by the Leader of the House. My experience and simple arithmetic say that, as I understand there are 36 amendments which the Senate are getting to at midnight and given that we know there are Independent senators enthusiastically speaking about all of them at 10 minutes each, that is six hours. I just thought I would mention that to make your day. I thought you would all like that.

I would like to start my thanks with the non-politicians and then come to the people who come to this place as elected representatives subsequently. I do not wish to add many people to the list of those who have been commented on by the three leaders and, on behalf of the opposition, by the Leader of the Opposition, but I do want to make specific reference to some who particularly assist me as Manager of Opposition Business. I thank the Parliamentary Liaison Office staff. Others have properly mentioned Alistair Sherwin, who does that job now, and his staff, Helen and Pam. But I want to also thank the previous PLO, Matt Minogue, who did a first-class job and whose assistance and cooperation we appreciated.

I join with those who thank the clerks, Ian Harris and Bernard Wright. Oppositions are very dependent upon the skills and knowledge of the clerks, particularly in our case because of the necessary arrangements with Bernard Wright. I want to thank him personally and on behalf of the opposition for his tremendous work. I thank the Clerk of the House of Representatives. All the clerks and their staff are of incredible value to the House in the way in which the leaders have commented on and which I simply reiterate. The opposition are particularly dependent upon some, and we thank Bernard and those who work with him.

Similarly, we thank those in the Table Office and I join in thanking the Serjeant-at-Arms and her staff. I share the amazement at the way in which Hansard staff manage to turn what we have to say into such reasonable sounding and, usually, even grammatical contributions. When I am here listening, it is not so evident to me as when I subsequently read it. It must be something in my hearing that is defective but, anyway, Hansard does a wonderful job and I, at least, am grateful, because I have a spouse who is very concerned about grammatical manners and she manages to only read, not hear, what I say and she thinks I speak grammatically in this place, so I am grateful for that.

The Parliamentary Library is always of fundamental significance to an opposition, because it drives our research capacity in the way that nothing else can. I would like to add to our general thanks to the Parliamentary Library and their staff my particular thanks to those who have assisted me in the transition to my new responsibilities in indigenous affairs and in the arts. They have been incredibly helpful to me in the transition. I will not name them; they know who they are and I thank them. I always particularly enjoy the opportunity to thank the attendants in the chamber and around the building. As a member who represents the ACT and who spends more time in the building when the House is not sitting than most, the good humour, courtesy and friendship of those people is something I value, and all of us in the opposition value the work that they do. I thank Kate and the staff at the Members Dining Room, the staff at the Staff Cafeteria, the people at Aussies, the transport people, Joint House and, in particular, the cleaning staff, who seem to have a very difficult time sometimes around here, but we value the work that they do. I thank the switchboard staff and the volunteers. It is too long a list and they have been mentioned by others; it would be inappropriate and time wasting to go through them all. We thank them for their work.

I want to mention two other groups in particular because of the assistance they give the opposition in general and to me in particular. I think the Parliamentary Education Office are an undervalued resource around the parliament. Because I am here when others are not, I often get the opportunity to speak at functions which they put on—educational events which they arrange for students and others—and I think they do a marvellous and undervalued job. On behalf of others, I thought I would thank the staff at the Health and Recreation Centre, given that I have not made an appearance there all year.

talk.start.para: —I was going to say, I haven't seen you there.
—No. I finally made a wise economic decision and let my membership lapse. It was one of the several wastes of money that I was undertaking.
—You're not becoming an economic rationalist, are you, Bob?

—No, just a sloth. It is trying to make some sort of virtue out of my sloth. On behalf of everybody else, I thank them. They do a marvellous job and they keep people who in the rest of their life are not quite so healthy somewhere near a state of reasonable health, and we are grateful for that.

speech.para: I now turn to the elected representatives, and I endorse the general remarks made by the Leader of the Opposition, the Prime Minister and the Leader of the National Party about good wishes to all the members on both sides. We have robust debate and some heated conflicts from time to time but we hope that, in the period between now and when the parliament resumes, everybody has a good time with their families and is rested, recuperated and happy when they return in February. What happens after that, time will tell.

I want to thank one person that the Leader of the Opposition always fails to thank, and that is our leader and my friend and colleague Kim Beazley. On behalf of all the opposition, I want to thank Kim for another magnificent year's leadership of our party. He has been a friend of mine a very long time and I appreciate the opportunity to work closely with him. On behalf of all my colleagues, I also want to thank Susie for the support she gives to Kim and the way in which she is a source of good spirit and good humour at the many functions which she attends on behalf of the party with Kim. We thank her and we hope Kim, Susie and Rachel have a really terrific Christmas.

I want to thank you, Mr Speaker. It has been a pretty robust couple of weeks. You have not looked like you have been enjoying it in the last couple of weeks as much as you usually do. Some of the twinkle in the eye has been dulled just a little and there has been a little bit of an edge in the voice. It has been a hard fortnight for all of us. But we thank you for the very genuine attempts we know that you have made over the year to make this place work well and, sometimes, to give us a chance to do things which the government thinks you should not give us. We are grateful for that. We know sometimes you pay a price for it and we appreciate it. We appreciate the work of the Deputy Speaker and the Second Deputy Speaker, our colleague Harry Jenkins, who we know will make a great Speaker when the time comes. We thank all three of you for the way in which you preside and we thank the other Presiding Officers.

We would like to thank the whips for both sides. It is not usual for us to thank the whip on the other side, but we think recently Ronno has done a terrific job and we have enjoyed it very much. He and Leo do make the place much more entertaining, and when they start debating each other across the chamber, it might not be the most edifying contribution but it is often the most entertaining. The place does work better because of them and I particularly want to thank Leo, Rod and Bob. I have the title `Manager of Opposition Business' but everybody knows that it is really Joan and Ann who manage it, and we are grateful to them. They sometimes make us look organised and, when they do not, it is not their fault. Also, after them, the next contribution is made by Leo, Rod and Bob, and I thank them for the enormous work they do, their unfailing focus on the arithmetic of this place and their almost great success this year in getting the 57-all. This year, I have enjoyed working with them again.

I thank the deputy leader, Simon, who has always been a very effective supporter of Kim and of great value to me in discharging this function. I want to thank the Leader of the House and his staff—in particular, Brett Hogan. We have not had cause to work so closely together this year. The way the business has flowed has not meant the level of interaction has been as much as in other years. We have had some colourful descriptions of each other's contributions in these valedictories in the past, but I do thank him because, when we need to, we can work together effectively. We will try and do it again tonight so we do not allow the Senate to drive us all mad. I thank you very much.

I want to thank all the caucus colleagues for their fortitude and support. Sometimes we ask them to do only the slightly ridiculous, and sometimes the absolutely bizarre. They usually do it with good humour and skill. And sometimes we ask them to do it at ridiculously short notice, and they carry that out with a bit of style and I am grateful for that.

We are all very dependent on the staff around this place. I thank in general all the staff, particularly of the frontbench members, but I want to pick out one who is a friend. He came to work for the Labor Party when we were in government. He worked for me, and subsequently worked for Kim and then for Simon. That is my friend John Flannery, who is leaving in about two weeks time. I want to thank him for many years of good service to us and I hope that, as he goes on to his new career, he has an opportunity to spend more time with his lovely wife and his children—including another one of those new babies that has come along on our side of the show. Boy, are we going to win an election in about 18 years! We have just about got it fixed already. I hope we don't have to wait that long, but we have got it fixed up if we do. I wish John well and hope he is very successful. I thank my own staff here and in the electorate office, and my family and that of all the colleagues who have enabled us to work here.

I conclude, as I do every year, by thanking the electors of Fraser. In my capacity as shadow minister, and particularly in this new job, I travel a lot. I am away from the electorate a lot. They are very understanding and supportive and I thank them for their cooperation, their understanding, their contribution as I travel the electorate on the issues of concern to the nation and for the great privilege they do in continuing to send me here to represent them.

talk.start.para: —I join with my colleagues in passing good wishes to all members of the House and to all their support staff and others who work here. I thank them for their work of the last 12 months.

speech.para: I start with you, Mr Speaker, and thank you for the work that you have done, and also thank the deputy speakers. Mr Speaker, on a rough calculation this year, you have had to deal with 668 beautifully crafted questions, questions which go to the heart of the current issues before the parliament, and another 668 questions that really one would not have bothered to ask with the benefit of hindsight. That makes a total of 1,336 asked for the year—not as many as last year, when the figure was 1,370, but running at nearly 19 questions at question time. That is indicative of the various issues and the importance of question time for all members of the House. I thank you for your work and also, as I say, thank the deputy speakers.

I do not have any particular order, but I also want to thank my family early in these remarks. I have four sons and a daughter-in-law—and my wife, Julie, of course. I have one son in London. I have actually seen a lot of him this year—mainly in the newspapers! We are not seeing him at Christmas, but we are going to take up the suggestion of having a decent break this year and I daresay I will hear from him on the phone.

talk.start.para: —At his expense!

—At his expense. Families are very important, and I am very lucky with the support that I have from my family. I also thank those on the opposition side. Someone did say to me that the Manager of Opposition Business would be a better Leader of the House than Manager of Opposition Business, but we appreciate the cooperation we achieve when we achieve it. That goes likewise to the Chief Opposition Whip, who is certainly one of the characters of the House. We thank you for that cooperation. I particularly thank the Chief Government Whip, who I believe does a tremendous job. He does take a big load in the running of the House. He makes my life a lot easier in the sense that he makes decisions and he definitely has a firm hand on the operations of the House. That makes a big difference to the efficiency of the House. I also thank the other whips—Stewart McArthur, Kay Elson, John Forrest and Paul Neville—for the support they give him and the work that they do. The whips office staff are very important too—Geraldine Rath, Leander Klohs and Cay McVeigh—to him, and therefore to all of us. The PLO staff have been mentioned. Alistair Sherwin is doing a very good job, in my view. We thank Pam Bache and Helen Tudor as well.

speech.para: The parliamentary staff have all been mentioned, but I do want to add my own personal thanks to them, particularly to Ian Harris and Bernard Wright. As others have said, they provide impartial, good advice—and they give it to you pretty quickly too, which, in the heat of the moment, is the only advice that is of any use to you. I thank you for that and I thank all your staff. I thank the chamber research office, Hansard and the Parliamentary Library. The security officers are, of course, very important to members in their work—and the cleaners as well; I reckon they do a pretty good job around here, and put up with a lot as well. There are also the people who answer the phone, the receptionists and telephonists. The Comcar drivers have had a mention, and the Reps transport people. There are the dining room staff. Kate in particular looks after all of us on an individual basis. We thank you, Kate. Lizzie is still doing my hair—though doing less of it as the years go on! She is a great person as well.

talk.start.para: —She can do yours and mine together.

—We could get a discount! I thank the PM and my ministerial colleagues. It is a good team, as the PM himself said, but it makes the team to have a good leader for the team. The PM brings a lot of qualities. He has a very even temperament, if I may say so, which is an absolute prerequisite, I reckon, for that job—certainly for everybody who has to deal with him. He has also had a lot of experience. I have known some people over the years who have had a lot of experience and it does not seem to have added much to them. Some people have had a lot of experience and it makes all the difference. I thank him for his experience and his consideration through the year. Like the previous speaker, the member for Fraser, I do not want to go over all the broad matters, but from my point of view, when I think back on this last 12 months, there has been a hell of a lot on our plate and we have done a hell of a lot as a government, in my view. For all the ups and downs of politics, it definitely makes it worth while when things are being done.

speech.para: I will quickly run through some of the things we have done. Tax reform is very important to me personally because I had three years running around the country on the GST. I am not the only one who has been on that bandwagon, but getting that through was a tremendous tribute to the PM—and, I should say, to the Treasurer, because having to handle every question and all the detail and carry it all around in your head is a very big task. It is incredible pressure. I think the Treasurer has done a magnificent job, as the PM said. Roads: that is a very big thing, a very important thing. The defence white paper has, I think, been a very important thing for the government. It is a hallmark issue on our side of politics, and that was great. David Kemp secured his education package tonight. I was once involved in starting a non-government school. I consider that issue very important, and it is great to see that get through. But, again, the PM provided a lot of leadership on that one. The salinity one is the other one I will briefly mention, because environmental issues are very important. Some environmental issues have had more profile than the substance of this particular one. A lot has been done, and I do thank him and the colleagues. I want to mention the PM's staff, too. I have a lot to do with Tony Nutt and Arthur Sinodinos, and I thank them both personally for their friendship and their professionalism. Brett and I have a lot to do with Malcolm Hazell on the running of the House, so I thank him.

I also thank the Liberal Party organisation. Liberal Party people outside the parliamentary party are of course also important in our working lives. Lynton Crosby has been mentioned, but I thank all the state directors around the country for their work during the year. I particularly thank the Deputy Leader of the House, Peter McGauran, the member for Gippsland. Again, I work with Peter virtually every day of the year talking about daily political issues, tactics and the like, and I thank him for the work that he does. David Kemp has a bit to do with some aspects of that as well, and I thank David personally.

In terms of my own ministerial staff, my chief of staff, Peter Hendy, is a very professional operator, and I thank him. Also, Peter Anderson, MaryJo Fisher, Ian Hanke, Jackie Jurd, Brett Hogan—who has been doing the House stuff whilst Cate Clunies-Ross has been off having their first child—Doug Campbell, Daniel Clode, Katrina Edwards, Emma Heales and David Hickman, who left us during the year. And of course there are Sadie McHugh, who is very well-regarded, I must say, Calvin McDonald and Janine Pitt. My electorate staff are the shadow members for Flinders. This can be a tiresome task at times and it is certainly a lonely task as well. But I do thank them. Jill Fletcher had a beer keg through the window at one stage during the year. When it was followed by a hose on a Sunday night it got a bit wet and they had to move the office.

talk.start.para: —It still got through the window—that was the problem. But they have had a lot on their plate this year. Liz Dart has been very good, although she has not been well recently and we certainly wish her well.

speech.para: In the portfolio I want to thank Tony Abbott, who is the junior minister. He is a very active junior minister and a good junior minister, I must say. We work as a team. Also, Mal Brough, who does a lot of work in the small business community. It is very important that we get around and talk to that constituency and he does a good job.

I also want to thank departmental officers. Peter Shergold runs a very good outfit. He worked very professionally for the other side when they were in. He has done a very professional job for this government and I have been fortunate to have him as a departmental head. I thank all his team; there are some professional people. We have a very working good relationship and I do thank them for the work that they do.

Lastly, I do thank all my colleagues. At this late hour I might briefly say that I have had my ups and down. Paul Keating once very kindly dubbed me as the Toltoy while I was on the back foot a bit at one stage there, a month or so ago. It is a very competitive business, politics, and you have to understand—
Government member—You're on your way back, China.

talk.start.para: —Thank you. It is a very competitive business, politics, and I think we all know that—those of us who have been around here for a while. But it does touch you, I must say, when you have got a bit of flak coming your way and people give you a bit of support. I do thank everybody for that in the last month or so. I can promise them that I am looking forward to coming back, all guns blazing, in February. Best wishes to all. Mr Speaker, thank you.

—It is customary for the Speaker to have the opportunity to conclude these remarks of good wishes at Christmas time. Let me then begin on the note on which the Leader of the House concluded and say that there are occasions when flak is flying and you are very grateful for the support of others. As one who in the last week or so has experienced something of that, I am grateful for the support—as the Leader of the Opposition is—of all those in the chamber, on both sides, who were in touch with my office. I am grateful to the Prime Minister and the Leader of the House for the fact—and I think this ought to be on the public record—that, as a Speaker, I am left entirely to my own resources in terms of decisions that are made, and I am grateful to them for the level of independence that they leave me. I should place on the record that I have never had a conservation with the Prime Minister about my role in the two years that I have had it. I am similarly grateful to the Leader of the Opposition and the Manager of Opposition Business for, in the two years that I have been the Speaker, there has been the opportunity to develop a relationship with them and it takes little more than eye contact now for me to know precisely what they are thinking—and, I suspect, for them to know precisely what I am thinking.

speech.para: I therefore say to the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the House, the Manager of Opposition Business and the Deputy Prime Minister, thank you for the warm remarks that you have extended to me and to Carolyn, my wife, who happens to be in the gallery this evening and to whom I am, of course, like everyone else, deeply indebted. She and our three children are, as others have observed tonight, the light of my life; I would have no particular purpose in life without them. As many of you are aware, in the last month the family has also been joined by a grandchild, and we are particularly delighted about that.

There are those who sadly think that for us to participate in this form of Christmas greeting is, as the Prime Minister alluded to, in some way hypocritical or facile or insincere. Those of us who are participants in this place know that is not the case. In fact, as many have said, it is inevitable that this is a place of fierce political competition, and Australians who are honest with themselves would not have it any other way. I am not proud of the occasional snide remark or the personal abuse that sometimes occurs but, for the overwhelming majority of the members of this House, the opportunity is here simply for debate rather than personal abuse. I pick up the sentiments partially expressed by the member for Isaacs in her first speech in this House when she called on all of us to spend more time focusing on policy issues and less time focusing on personal issues.

In this, as previous speakers have said, the Olympic year, I thought it quite appropriate to conclude the year with the statement used in the Celebrate Humanity promotional campaign during the Sydney Olympic Games. There are times when, sitting in the chair, I think of these words, as I suspect most of you do too. The words are: `You are my adversary but you are not my enemy, for your resistance gives me strength, your will gives me courage, your spirit enables me, and, though I aim to defeat you, should I succeed, I will not humiliate you. Instead I will honour you, for without you I am a lesser a person.' There are many times in this chamber when I see members on opposing sides honouring each other. I think of an event within the last month when the Prime Minister rose unexpectedly, from my point of view, to pay a sincere tribute to the Leader of the Opposition for 20 years service in this place. The Leader of the Opposition very graciously responded, indicating how much he had appreciated that sentiment. Sadly, it was not a sentiment that got front-page publicity or that most of Australia was aware of.

Those who make it possible for us to be in a parliament which is adversarial and at the same time cooperative—not as cooperative as we may sometimes want, but those who have been here long enough to know that that is in fact the underlying sentiment—have already been named, but I would like to pay a particular tribute, because of my role as Speaker, to the many people who as staff members in this place make it work. I must start with my Deputy Speaker, Mr Gary Nehl, and the second Deputy Speaker, Mr Harry Jenkins, and the members of the Speakers Panel who in fact occupy the chair and who endeavour—and I think most people would agree are successful—to impartially adjudicate on the many debates that occur in this place. I want to thank the Parliamentary Liaison Officer and the government and opposition whips and their staff.

I am more indebted than most to the Clerk of the House—I was going to say `my clerk' because I see him on such a regular basis—Mr Harris, and of course to Bernard, for the way in which they offer professional advice to everyone, for the way in which they ensure that everyone can come to them without fear or favour, and for the way in which their advice is always well founded. I also pay tribute to Laraine and Katrina in the Clerk's Office, to the clerk assistants, to the Table Office, the Chamber Research Office and their staff, to the people in the Sergeant-at-Arms' Office—Judy Middlebrook, Dalma and Barry—and the messengerial and security attendants.
