I have indicated that I will produce a report on the Eastern European situation and that I believe that Australia's relations with Eastern Europe can be significantly increased and improved, especially economic and trade relations, to the benefit of both Eastern European countries and Australia. The minister for trade has indicated, in particular, that he is interested in trying to increase what is a pretty low level of interaction between Australia and those countries of Eastern Europe. It is surprising that this situation exists because we have so many huge communities from those countries in Australia and we could certainly have a link between those countries and Australia, not only cultural but also economic, to benefit Australia and those nations. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Bundaberg East State School: Remembrance Day Service

talk.start.para: —The Bundaberg East State School is 114 years old and, in terms of that part of Queensland, the Wide Bay-Burnett area, it is one of the oldest schools in the district. Over the years its students have seen all the conflicts from the Boer War right through to East Timor—quite a unique experience. Its honour roll lists 52 brave ex-students who served in the AIF.

speech.para: I was singularly honoured on 10 November, the eve of Remembrance Day, to attend a moving and, indeed, inspiring service at the school. Surrounded by the students—some wearing their fathers' and grandfathers' service medals—parents and people from East Bundaberg, we assembled around a new memorial in the school's new courtyard. The memorial was funded through the Their Service—Our Heritage Commemorative Program for new memorials. In this setting, the Catafalque Party was posted by 12 Platoon Delta Company 9RQR. An extraordinarily moving service followed. The school choir, led by Jill Baxter, sang Mary Donnelly's song of peace and Dona Nobis Pacem. Following that, the dedication service was conducted by Major Lionel Parker from the Bundaberg Salvation Army, who also led the Lord's Prayer.

Following that, the students laid their wreaths. There is nothing particularly unusual about laying wreaths, but this was quite moving in the sense that the students had crafted the wreaths themselves. Some were on cardboard and were hand painted, some were made of little clusters of paper flowers and I think one or two even had natural flowers on them. So it was not just that someone had raced out and bought these things—this was the visible and emotional expression of the students themselves.

Earlier in the day and just prior to the service, John Wilson, the President of the Bundaberg RSL, I, representing the federal government, and John Panitz from the Bundaberg East State School Parents and Citizens Association addressed the gathering. Dave Wilkinson, the District Director of Education, unveiled the memorial, which was quite striking and beautifully set in surroundings that had been put there by the state government's construction authority Q Build. As we looked around at this very moving ceremony, we saw children who took a particular interest in what had happened to the people who had gone through that school over five generations.

I would particularly like on this occasion to compliment the principal of the school, Doug Ambrose, Remembrance Day coordinator and part of the school's faculty, Paul McMillen, and the East State School vice captains, Anna-Maree Bennett and Jonathan Hay, who assisted in the ceremony. The school captains, Trudy Sinnamon and Cale Cramer, recited the Ode of Remembrance, and The Last Post and Reveille were played. The ceremony closed with the national anthem played by the school's band.

It is good to know that the Their Service—Our Heritage Commemorative Program can bring such focus to a community. That focus was heightened by the quality of the student's input, by the sincerity of what they did, by the very moving way that they had constructed their own wreaths and by the general excellence that the principal, the coordinator and the faculty of the school brought together on that memorable occasion.

talk.start.para: —On Saturday, 26 November I was very pleased to attend the opening of the new wing at Dale Cottages, which is an aged care facility in my electorate of Canning. Today I want to place on record my congratulations to the board and the president, Mr Frank Green, who, a few days before the opening, was finishing off the reticulation himself to make sure that it was all ready to go on the Saturday. I also congratulate Trudy Hodges, the administrator, the board and the staff, who offer such a wonderful area for our seniors to live in where they can feel cared for and secure. In particular, I pay tribute to Mr Jack Murray whose dream this was.
(Mr Nehl)—Order! The time allowed for debate has expired.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Taxation Office: Superannuation Guarantee Compliance
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1563)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many complaints does the Australian Taxation Office have on its books concerning Superannuation Guarantee non compliance.
(2) During (a) 1998-99 and (b) 1999-2000 to date, how many Australian workers did not receive their full Superannuation Guarantee entitlements.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) currently has 7,814 active notifications from employees on its books regarding Superannuation Guarantee non-compliance.
(2) (a) As determined by the ATO's annual Superannuation Guarantee Compliance Survey, 8% of employees had insufficient contributions made on their behalf during 1998-99.
It is important to note that of the 8% who had insufficient contributions made, more than half had within 1% of the full amount contributed.
(b) The results of the ATO's Superannuation Guarantee Compliance Survey for the 1999-2000 year is currently not available. It is expected that the findings will be released within the next few weeks.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Taxation Office: Superannuation Guarantee Compliance
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1633)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has the Australian Tax Office (ATO) known since August 1996 that Chaucers Reception Centre in Melbourne was not paying superannuation on behalf of its employees; if so, why did it not take action until after JB and TM Catering went bankrupt in March 2000.
(2) What prospects do Chaucers former employees have of recovering the superannuation contributions to which they are entitled.
(3) How many other firms have not paid their employees their entitlements under the Superannuation Guarantee.
(4) Is the ATO enforcing Superannuation Guarantee compliance or has implementation of the goods and services tax precluded it from doing so.

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The ATO has been aware of Superannuation Guarantee (SG) issues with Chaucers Reception Centre since August 1996. The ATO commenced its action on this employer shortly after this date, not after the employer went bankrupt in March 2000.

(2) The ATO is unable to speculate on the former employees of Chaucer's prospects of receiving their entitlements under the SG. As this case is now on the public record, the ATO is able to state that a Proof of Debt has been lodged. This is now a matter for the administrator, D'Aloia Handberg, who was appointed on 21 March 2000.

Where an employer becomes bankrupt or insolvent, the ATO pursues any outstanding SG in line with the normal legal and procedural requirements relating to bankruptcy and insolvency administration eg. by lodging a Proof of Debt.

(3) The ATO's annual Superannuation Guarantee Compliance Research Survey revealed that in 1998/99; 71% of employers investigated were fully compliant with their SG obligations; 28% were partially compliant, and around 1% were fully non-compliant.
For those businesses who were partially compliant, the degree and magnitude of non-compliance was low, indicating only minor non-compliance.
(4) The ATO has not changed its compliance strategy in enforcement of the SG since the beginning of the implementation of the goods and services tax.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 August 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article in the Australian Financial Review on 8 August 2000 entitled “ATO keeps them posted”.

(2) Will the Australian Taxation Office and Australia Post no longer accept payment of HECS and income tax bills in person; if so, why has the option of paying tax bills at the tax office been removed.
(3) Is this removal a breach of the Taxpayers' Charter.
(4) Will he refer this matter to the Board of Taxation.

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The cashier service at all Australian Taxation Office (ATO) sites was withdrawn on 31 December 1999. The decision to close cashiers was made on the basis that less than 6% of ATO payments were processed through this facility, and of this number, almost all could be paid in person at any one of 4000 Australia Post sites.
There are a variety of payment methods currently available to taxpayers. These include:
-paying at a post office or licensed agency by cash or cheque (a $3000 cash limit applies and a payment advice must accompany payment);
-mailing payments to the address printed on the payment advice. Where a payment advice is not available, payments can be sent to the nearest ATO;
-by electronic funds transfer such as direct debit from a nominated bank account or a direct credit via desktop banking; and
-using the banking industry's BPay service via the phone or the internet.
A taxpayer wishing to make a HECS or income tax payment can now do so by using any of the payment methods listed above.

Due to the nature of voluntary payments, voluntary payers are not automatically provided with pre-printed ATO payment forms. However, without an ATO payment form, they are unable to make payments at Australia Post.

As such, as part of Tax Reform, the ATO has now implemented a service whereby voluntary payers can order payment advice booklets by phoning 13 24 78. The booklets contain personalised payment forms that can be used whenever the taxpayer wishes to make a voluntary payment, including income tax and HECS payments.
(3) The ATO does not believe that the closure of cashiers is a breach of the Taxpayers' Charter. The ATO has provided a wide range of payment options to suit the needs of taxpayers.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 September 2000:

quote.para: (1) If a charitable organisation has had its funding cut by virtue of receiving a Commonwealth Jobs Network grant gross up of only 7.2 per cent following the introduction of the GST, can it claim a top up adjustment from the Commonwealth.
(2) If not, are they disadvantaged in providing those services compared to non-charitable organisations in the employment services sector.

(3) What is the reason for differential approaches between Departments, including the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business (DEWRSB), the Department of Family and Community Services (DFACS) and the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DETYA) in the percentages used to gross up grants to charitable organisations providing government funded services following the introduction of the GST.

talk.start.para: —As Minister for Finance and Administration, I am pleased to respond on the Treasure's behalf:

quote.para: (1) DEWRSB does not provide grants to Job Network service providers.

DEWRSB pays Job Network service providers on the basis of outcomes achieved. The payments made are based on a contract won as a result of a competitive tender process. The most recent tender process awarded contracts for the three-year period commencing 28 February 2000. In the Request for Tender (RFT) documentation, tenderers were asked to submit prices inclusive of the Goods and Services Tax (GST). On the basis of advice from Treasury, information on how to manage the New Tax System issues in the Job Network tender was included in the RFT documentation

(2) Charitable organisations providing Job Network Services are not disadvantaged in providing these services compared to non-charitable organisations in the employment services sector. Refer to the response to (1) above.
(3) DEWRSB does not provide grants to Job Network service providers.

It is the policy of DEWRSB, DFACS and DETYA to gross up grants to charitable organisations that are registered for the GST by 10 per cent, as per the Commonwealth Government's policy announced by the Treasurer on 9 December 1999.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 3 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question no. 1761, (Hansard, 3 October 2000, page 20674), are all imported second hand or used buses and coaches required to comply with Australian Design Rules (ADRs); if so, what legislation or regulation specify the requirement.
(2) Is there a proposal to change this requirement; if so, (a) which states, organisations or individuals have requested a change and (b) for what purpose.

(3) What would be the (a) effect of any such change on the safety of passengers travelling in those imported second hand or used buses and coaches and (b) the cost of an imported second hand or used bus or coach relative to an Australian one.
(4) Which agency, department or authority is responsible for auditing imported second hand or used buses and coaches to ensure they comply with ADRs.
(5) How many audits has that organisation conducted each year since 1995, and how quickly are audits conducted after date of importation.
(6) How many second hand or used buses and coaches were imported in each year since 1995 and from which country were they imported.
(7) When audited, how many of these second hand or used buses and coaches were found not to comply with ADRs.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. All second hand or used buses and coaches supplied to the Australian market are required to comply with Australian Design Rules (ADRs) when they begin to be used in transport. The requirement is specified under the provisions of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989. This applies equally to buses and coaches built locally or imported.
(3) Not applicable. No changes are envisaged to the requirement that imported second hand or used buses and coaches comply with the ADRs.
(4) The Department of Transport and Regional Services is responsible for auditing all vehicle manufacturers supplying the Australian market to ensure compliance with the ADRs.
(5) The Vehicle Safety Standards Branch of the Department conducted an audit on an overseas bus production plant that supplied second hand buses to Australia in 1998.

An audit can be conducted soon after the bus manufacturer is granted an approval to fit compliance plates to the vehicles. However, the actual audit date can depend on the location of the production plant and the Department of Transport and Regional Services' overseas audit schedule.

(6) This information is not available as the Department of Transport and Regional Services does not keep records of vehicles that are actually imported. From 1995 to 1 October 2000, applications to import 17 second hand or used buses were approved by the Administrator of Vehicle Standards.

(7) Each bus or coach is not individually inspected at an audit. The purpose of a conformity of production audit is to enable the Administrator of Vehicle Standards to gain assurance that series produced vehicles comply with the Australian Design Rules by providing an avenue for manufacturers to demonstrate the controls maintained over those design, testing, purchasing and vehicle manufacturing processes which impinge on the Australian Design Rules.

Deficiencies in the quality assurance system of bus and coach manufacturers have been found during routine conformity of production audits. These deficiencies have been rectified to the satisfaction of the Administrator of Vehicle Standards.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 3 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Did he state at a conference on the Gold Coast on 14 July 2000 that the Melbourne to Brisbane railway had the capacity to proceed without government funding.
(2) Has the federal government been approached for financial assistance for the project; if so, what was the nature of the approach.
(3) Will the government provide financial assistance for the project.
(4) On what basis were members of parliament and local government leaders appointed by him to a Task Force Committee to examine the Melbourne to Brisbane railway.
(5) Who was appointed to the Task Force Committee.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) On 14 July 2000 I announced that the pre-feasibility study conducted for the Australian Transport and Energy Corridor Limited into the proposal to build an inland railway between Melbourne and Brisbane had concluded that minimalist options demonstrated strong financial viability and could be implemented on a no cost to Government basis.

(2) and (3) The federal government contributed $300,000 towards the pre-feasibility study. The federal government is also to contribute $30,000 to a market study of the Toowoomba/Emerald/ Gladstone section.
(4) and (5) A Committee comprising the Hon Mal Brough MP (Chair), Mr Tony Lawler MP, Mrs Kay Hull MP and Mr Ian
Macfarlane MP provided the federal government with initial advice on the inland railway proposal.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) In light of the report made in the Australian Financial Review of 3 October 2000 in respect to the Speedrail project, what is the government's estimate of the cost of the Speedrail project.
(2) What route is envisaged for the Speedrail project.

(3) Is he able to say whether denying funding to the Speedrail project would undermine the viability of finding a site for the location of a further Sydney airport outside the Sydney Basin and airshed.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Speedrail estimates on its website and in its publicity material that the total project cost will be $4.8billion. (see www.speedrail.com.au).

(2) The governments have not made a decision on the future of the project at this time. If the project were to proceed an Environment Impact Assessment would be undertaken before the final route was determined.
(3) The Sydney-Canberra Very High Speed Train and Sydney's future airport needs are currently being considered by the Government.

subdebateinfo.title: Second Sydney Airport: Speedrail and Western Sydney Orbital
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2027)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say whether the `loss of crucial support' for Speedrail as expressed in the Australian Financial Review of 3 October 2000 and the decision to commit a large amount of money to the Western Sydney Orbital Link mitigates against alternatives to Badgery's creek as the site for Sydney's Second Airport.
(2) Will he consider a comprehensive Environmental Impact Statement on the site selection process that considers sites other than Badgery's Creek.
(3) Is he able to say what is the relationship between Macquarie Bank and its subsidiaries and Infrastructure Trust of Australia.

(4) Is he able to say what is the relationship between Macquarie Bank and its subsidiaries and (a) the Airport Motorway (b) the M5 Motorway and (c) the M2 Motorway projects, which are all located in Sydney.
(5) Who has advised the Government in respect to the estimates of the costs of (a) The Western Sydney Orbital Link and (b) the Speedrail proposal.
(6) Is he able to say whether Macquarie Bank has had any part in the cost estimations relied upon by the Government in influencing its transport policy agenda.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The Government is currently considering Sydney's future airport needs. Further environmental assessment of sites other than Badgery's Creek is not relevant at this time.

(3) and (4) The Macquarie Bank is a major investor in infrastructure in Australia and overseas. Macquarie Bank has been involved in the projects referred to. The exact relationship between Macquarie Bank and the private consortia developing and managing the project would be a commercial matter and those relationships may change over time as the parties involved adapt to their changing commercial environments.
(5) (a) Roads and Traffic Authority (b) Westpac Corporate Finance.
(6) Macquarie Bank has not advised the Commonwealth on cost estimates for WSO or Sydney-Canberra VHST.

subdebateinfo.title: Alice Springs to Darwin Railway: Funding Arrangements
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2036)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 1196 (Hansard, 3 April 2000, page 14531), is he aware of the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics estimate that the Alice Springs to Darwin railway has a benefit-cost ratio of 0.56:1; if so, does he regard this as an accurate estimate.

(2) For the (a) 1999-2000 and (b) 2000-01 Budgets, does the reporting of the Government's expenditure on the Alice Springs to Darwin railway comply with its accrual accounting guidelines; if so, what are the details.
(3) Has the Government recorded (a) the expected outcomes and (b) a benefit-cost ratio for the Alice Springs to Darwin railway in its last two Budget statements; if so, what are the details.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) A number of feasibility studies have been conducted over the years into the viability of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway.

The most recent study I am advised of was published in October 1999 by Booz Allen and Hamilton. This study, which was commissioned by the Northern Territory Department of Transport and Works, found that the project has a benefit-cost ratio of 1.88.
(2) Yes.
(3) (a) and (b) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 30 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Are compensation payments under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act payable to employees over 65 years of age; if not, what options has he considered to amend the act to provide for such payments to employees over the age of 65 years.
(2) Has he or his department issued a discussion paper or sought the views of relevant stakeholders in relation to such a proposal.
(3) Will he amend the act to provide for weekly compensation payments to employees over the age of 65 years; if so, when.

talker.name: Reith, Peter, MP
Mr Reith
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The government's policy is to remove barriers to employees working beyond 65 years of age and it has been progressively taking action to achieve this aim. Following the removal of the mandatory retiring age in the Public Service Act 1999, the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (the SRC Act) was amended to enable compensation payments to be payable to an Australian Public Service (APS) employee if he or she is injured at any age after the age of 63 years for a maximum of 104 weeks (whether consecutive or not) during which the employee is incapacitated. A further amendment is proposed to apply the new arrangements to all employees covered by the SRC Act.

(2) A discussion paper has not been issued on this matter. As the SRC Act has already been amended in relation to APS employees and a further amendment is proposed to extend the arrangements to all employers covered by the SRC Act, it has not been necessary to seek any further views.
(3) It is expected that the further amendment to the SRC Act will be introduced in the current parliamentary sitting.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 1 November 2000:

quote.para: Have there been breaches of the legislated cap of 80 movements per hour at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport; if so, (a) when were the breaches, (b) has he sought an explanation from Airservices Australia for the breaches and (c) what penalties or punitive action has he imposed for the breaches.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (a) & (b) Under the Sydney Airport Demand Management Act 1997, Airservices Australia is required to report to me on the extent of infringements (if any) of the maximum movement scheduling limit in each quarter. On 30 August 2000 I tabled a report detailing four hours in which the maximum movement limit was exceeded for the quarter ending 30 June 2000 including explanations for the events. Airservices Australia has also provided me with a report of movements for the quarter ending 30 September 2000. The report will be tabled before 6 December 2000.

(c) No fines have been issued under the Act to date. The Sydney Airport Demand Management Act provides that the 80 movement per hour cap is to be the planning basis for the Slot Management Scheme established pursuant to the Act. The Sydney Airport Demand Management Act does not provide for penalties for breaches of the cap as such. Instead, the penalties for which the Act provides relate to breaches of the Slot Management Scheme (ie, aircraft which operate without a slot, or aircraft which operate outside allowed time limits which apply to an allocated slot).

The movements are assessed by the Slot Compliance Committee which is currently finalising its consideration of all movements which took place during the Northern Summer Scheduling Season (ie from the end of March until the end of October). However, where a delay to an aircraft is caused by factors outside the operator's control (eg weather, operational constraints applied by Airservices or the airport, or safety factors) no penalty is imposed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 November 2000:

quote.para: Further to the answer to question no. 1746 (Hansard, 6 November 2000, page 22247) what do the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, the Australian Transport Safety Bureau or Airservices Australia regard as an acceptable safety hazard in respect to weather conditions applying to the landing and take off of aircraft.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has determined that air traffic control should not nominate a runway for use when there is a crosswind of more than 20 knots and an alternative runway is available. The new crosswind limit will apply to all airports with more than one runway, including Sydney Airport.

CASA has also determined that Airservices Australia must provide pilots with an update of wind conditions when it issues takeoff and landing clearances, except at GAAP airports where the large number of aircraft in the circuit would make it impractical.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 8 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to the release of the Interim Factual Report 200002157 into the accident involving the Piper Chieftain VH-MZK near the Whyalla Aerodrome on 31 May 2000, will draft copies of that report be circulated to any parties; if so, (a) to whom and (b) what authority do these parties have to make changes to that report.
(2) Who will sign off on the report before it is released.
(3) Will the report be released to the families of those who died in the accident before it is released publicly.
(4) When does he expect a final report into this accident to be released.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) In accordance with established Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) policy, draft copies of Interim Factual Reports are not circulated for comment from interested parties to the investigation. A draft copy of the Final Report of the Whyalla Airlines investigation will be circulated for comment by interested parties.
(a) The interested parties include:
Whyalla Airlines;
the family of the pilot in command;
the Civil Aviation Safety Authority;
Airservices Australia;
the aircraft manufacturer;
the South Australia Government;
the South Australia Police; and
the South Australia State Coroner.
Other parties with an interest include:
the families of the deceased passengers; and others who have expressed an interest.
A party with an interest may be provided with a copy of the draft final report for comment, if a request for a copy of the draft has been lodged with the ATSB.
Copies of draft final reports, classified by ATSB as high profile, are provided on a routine basis, for information only, to the:
Minister for Transport and Regional Services;
Secretary and Deputy Secretaries, Department of Transport & Regional Services (DoTRS);
First Assistant Secretary, Aviation Division (DoTRS);
First Assistant Secretary, Airports Division (DoTRS).

(b) Interested parties are normally given 28 days to comment on the draft final report, and can suggest changes to the report only if supported by evidence. The ATSB assesses such evidence and decides whether changes should be made. The parties have no authority to make changes themselves.

(2) Approval to release the Final Report will be signed by the Executive Director, ATSB. Approval to release the draft report to interested parties will be by the Director, Air Safety Investigation, ATSB.

(3) Copies of the Interim Factual Report were released to the families of the deceased on 19 September 2000, five working days prior to public release on 26 September 2000. The families will also be provided with copies of the Final Report five working days before public release.
(4) The ATSB has advised that the Final Report of the Whyalla Airlines investigation is expected to be released at about the end of March 2001.

subdebateinfo.title: National Schools Drug Education Strategy: Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2151)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) How much of the $27.3m over four years allocated under the Tough on Drugs program to his Department for the development and implementation of the National Schools Drug Education Strategy has been spent.
(2) Which organisations and experts has his Department consulted in developing the Strategy.
(3) Have any consultants been employed to assist in the development of the Strategy or in any materials; if so, what are the details of the consultants employed, costs and tasks undertaken.
(4) What materials have been produced, or what programs or projects have been funded, under the Strategy.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Commonwealth Government has provided $27.3 million over four years for school drug education under the Tough on Drugs initiative. This funding is directed towards the enhancement of school drug education programmes ($18 million for the National School Drug Education Strategy) and the management of drug related issues and incidents in schools ($9.3 million for the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) agreed measures).

At the end of November 2000, $5.1 million had been expended. In addition, a further $17 million is either committed or allocated to projects where contractual arrangements are currently being finalised.

(2) The National School Drug Education Strategy was developed by the National Advisory Committee on School Drug Education on the basis of a collaborative, intersectoral coordinated approach to drug education and reflects consideration of the issues raised by stakeholder groups in the initial consultations. Members of the National Advisory Committee on School Drug Education who were involved in the development of the Strategy are listed on page 22 of the Strategy (Attachment A). Organisations who responded to national consultations are listed on page 20 of the Strategy (Attachment B).
(3) Details of the consultants employed, costs and tasks undertaken are listed here.

para.inline: Information for Parents on the National School Drug Education Strategy - writer.

entry.para: Caring for the Kids in Our Community Satellite Broadcast - develop and deliver a satellite broadcast to Australian school communities.
New South Wales Department of Education and Training through its Open Training and Education Network.
Caring for the Kids in Our Community Satellite Broadcast - develop a concept plan which provided options for organising the satellite broadcast.
Drug Referral Information Service Project - enhancements to the Australian Drug Information Network
Australian School Students Alcohol and Drug Survey - collation and analysis of additional questions.
Review of the Principles for Drug Education in Schools
The National Drug Research Institute, Curtin University in association with the Australian Drug Foundation
Effective Implementation Practice in Relation to School Drug Education
The Australian Drug Foundation in association with the National Drug Research Institute, Curtin University
Review of Pre-Service teacher training in school drug education
Health Education Unit, the University of Sydney
Identification of and development of guidelines for implementing performance management processes for State and Territory based projects under the National School Drug Education Strategy

quote.para: *Costs exclusive of GST
(4) In addition to the projects listed in (3), the following projects are being funded.

Government and non-government State/Territory school jurisdictions have submitted a collaborative cross-sectoral State/Territory proposal for funding of local school community drug summits. The summits aim to bring school staff, parents and key community members together to encourage stronger, broader and more integrated community engagement and support in addressing illicit and unsanctioned drug use by young people. The summits will also provide a vehicle to disseminate the national approach agreed by COAG to managing drug use in schools.
Contracts are currently being negotiated. The summits are expected to commence early in the 2001 school year and will be delivered over the following three years.
State and Territory school drug education initiatives

The National School Drug Education Strategy currently has contracts with State and Territory government and non-government education authorities. Proposals have also been sought for the next 3 years to support school drug education in government and non-government schools systems.

entry.para: Initiatives that support school based drug education and parent and community involvement. The focus is on primary education, policy and practice, parent and community partnerships, lighthouse grants, information dissemination and research.

Research projects that extend and enhance activities under the Victorian Government's Turning the Tide initiative on areas such as effective drug education, peer drug education, responding to illicit drug use, tobacco education and Koori drug education.
Strong emphasis on professional development for teachers and principals, through development of resources and research on baseline performance data.

The implementation of whole school community approaches and supporting professional development for teachers including development of drug education guidelines, dissemination of best practice and information programmes for parents.
Focus on school and community partnerships through a School Community Grant Scheme and a School Community Transition project.
Focus on school and community partnerships through the establishment of school community demonstration projects and the subsequent development of models for use by other schools.
Innovative project on the delivery of drug education in rural/remote Aboriginal communities and support activities in the urban context.
Development of whole school approaches to drug education, by the means of school drug education strategies for self identified schools.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 30 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answers to questions No. 1915 (Hansard, 27 November 2000, page 20075), No. 1970 (Hansard, 27 November 2000, page 20077) and No. 2066 (Hansard, 6 November 2000, page 22261), has his attention been drawn to a statement by Father Tom Doyle, Deputy Chairman of the National Catholic Education Commission, before a Senate Committee on 22 August 2000 that the Catholic systems would have actually benefited more from an aggregation according to SES levels; if so, does he agree with this assessment.
(2) Did the SES simulation project model the likely impact of SES funding on Catholic systemic schools; if so, (a) what are the details and (b) what was the projected impact of every school modelled?

(3) Has his Department advised any Member of the House of the likely impact of the application of the SES model on Catholic systemic schools; if so, (a) what are the details and (b) what is the likely impact.

(4) For every year from 2001 to 2004, what is the difference in funding between the amounts allocated to Catholic systems in the State Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill and an aggregation according to SES levels?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Initial estimates, based on simulated SES scores, indicated that this would be the case.

(2) The 1998 SES Simulation Project was undertaken to test the validity and feasibility of an SES approach to funding non-government schools. As participation in the Project was purely voluntary and on the basis that the data provided by schools would be treated in confidence with no actual funding implications, it would be inappropriate to provide detailed information about individual schools or systems.

(3) As Catholic systems will be funded at 56.2% of AGSRC (51.2% for the ACT) for the 2001-2004 quadrennium and not on the basis of the SES scores of their individual schools, my Department did not collect from Catholic systemic schools the data required for the calculation of individual school SES scores. Consequently, there is no basis on which to determine the likely impact of the application of the SES model on Catholic systemic schools.
